Speaker: Mr WEBB
Title: CIVIL AVIATION
text: I address a question to the Minister for Civil Aviation. Is there a curfew on the movement of jet aircraft at Sydney and Melbourne airports because of the noise? Is it difficult to introduce a curfew at Perth airport because international flights through Perth arrive and depart in the early morning? As Perth can expect more jet services in the future, and possibly bigger and noisier jet aircraft, what consideration is being given to reducing the noise nuisance at that airport? Wfll consideration be given to building a new airport away from built-up areas?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: CIVIL AVIATION
text: The answer to the latter part of the question is that no consideration will be given to the construction of another airport away from the built-up areas of Perth or of other centres at the moment unless sheer pressure on the facilities causes such a situation to arise. The noise question causes much concern to my Department as well as to people living in the vicinity of airports and action is taken by various means, including the determination of approach paths, to try to avoid it as much as possible. Restrictions are placed on the movement of aircraft at all major airports in Australia at night. This, of course, applies to Perth as well as to other airports. There are circumstances where, in an emergency, it may be necessary for this regulation to be varied, but under normal circumstances traffic is permitted within certain specified times during the hours of darkness. I will look at the situation as it applies to Perth in relation to the international services that are being provided to see whether anything further can be done to avoid this problem, which I know is difficult particuto larly with the increased number of jet vices that are being provided. text: I address a question to the Acting Minister for Trade and. Industry about the entry of Australian butter into the United Kingdom. text: Australia' s butter ports to the United Kingdom, as the honourdefence able member explained, were initiaUy specified under the Ottawa Agreement, which provided for unlimited entry of AusSi tralian and New Zealand butter into the United Kingdom market. In 1961 the treaty was varied to the extent that quotas were introduced. In 1963 the surcharge of ISs sterling per cent was removed. This was a preference given to Australian and New Zealand butter. In 1966 the United figures Kingdom-New Zealand Trade Agreement came into operation. At this point specified rights of access were granted up till 1972. The 15s preference was renewed, but it was waived on the condition that New Zealand continued to retain free access for certain quotas. Australia also retains quotas, which are determined on an annual basis and are subject to review, I underbuilding stand, about lst April each year. As the honourable member has explained, the quotas introduced in 1962 have operated subject to cancellation by either party six months notice. To date Britain has not chosen to exercise this prerogative, either during the earlier application to join the European Economic Community in 1962 or during the Kennedy Round of negotiations which have continued since 1963. At this stage I see no reasonable likelihood of Britain choosing to exercise this option. However, as to the possible effect of Britain's entry into the European Economic Community and the comparable position New Zealand, at this stage it is too early ascertain the situation. I can assure the honourable member and other honourable that members that the position at this stage least is that there is no likelihood of Britain exercising that option. NA

Honourable members will be aware ihat the Minister for the Interior is responsible for the administration of the Australian Capital Territory. This function is performed in the main through the Department of the Interior, with the Department of Health and the Attorney-General's Department also playing important parts. Many other Commonwealth departments and instrumentalities are also involved. From time to time the people of the Australian Capital Territory, or at least some of them, have pressed for changes in the present system, under which their only elected representatives are a member in this House and eight members on the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council. I have given serious study to the present administrative arrangements, particularly in the light of the views expressed by the elected members on the Advisory Council that self government is an immediate need and that the present arrangements are unsatisfactory. On the other hand, many residents of the Territory have indicated that they would prefer the present system, with all its faults, to a system which they did not know. Having referred to the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council, I feel I should tell the House that the Council has a very real role in the current arrangements for the government and administration of the Territory. The elected members of the Council are there as the representatives of the people of this community, and both the members, and their electors, make full use of their rights to interest themselves in all matters which affect them. My Department and I spend a great deal of time in considering the proposals put forward by the Advisory Council, and in supplying answers to questions. Honourable members will get some indication of the activities of the Council when I tell them that the present Council, which took office just two and a half years ago, has submitted well over a hundred resolutions to me. This figure relates only to what I term principle issues, many of which haye In fact resulted in Council resubmitting various aspects of an issue to me two or three times by way of further resolutions. In addition, the Council has asked some 1,200 parliamentary-type questions on notice. The four nominated representatives on the Council have also replied to a host of questions without notice. As well as those motions which are passed as resolutions, there are vast numbers of motions which are not seconded or which are defeated after consideration. Although these do not reach me in the form of motions, they appear on the Council's agenda and thus involve a vast amount of work by officers in my Department in study and consideration prior to Council meetings. During the life of the present Advisory Council some 650 such motions have so far been listed on the notice paper and have received the appropriate consideration due to those matters which are raised by the elected representatives of the people. As residents in almost any other part of Australia could testify, the existence of a system of State or municipal government does not, of itself, solve any problems of government and administration; nor does it mean that all persons living under such a system find themselves without grievances or cause for complaint. This being the case, it is important for those who would press for changes in the present system in the Australian Capital Territory to ask themselves whether they are concerned about their lack of representative institutions per se, or whether they honestly believe that greater local control would result in a better system of administration, recognising that such a concept will mean different things to different people. If the desire of the Australian Capital Territory residents is for a more democratic system, based on traditional electoral responsibility, then it must be remembered that there is a wider democracy and a wider electoral responsibility which must also be accommodated. While the Government recognises that the Australian Capital Terrilory is the home of over 100,000 Australians, it is also an area of territory acquired by the Commonwealth in accorsimple dance with the Constitution in order fulfil a purpose which was specified in that Constitution. Underlying Canberra's conare stitutional role as the seat of government:a place where the central organs of the national government are located-is its legalistic but nonetheless important role the National Capital, a city whose design and construction must be carried out to such standards as will reflect credit on nation. It is these two concepts of. the seat of government and the National affect Capital which have for so long delayed transition to responsible self-government for the residents of this Territory and which must continue, for many years to come, to to influence the decisions of the governbest ment and parliament of the day on this important question. Having said this, however, I must also tell the House that, since becoming Minister for the Interior, I have been conState-type cerned about this matter and I resolved contribute to a solution if I could. Given the tradition of self-government at the State and municipal level throughout the rest of Australia, it has not been easy for me to accept with equanimity the situation in which this rapidly growing community is denied all representation, except for its Federal member who, for the first time, has full voting rights in this House, and Council which may only advise the continuing studies. Minister for the Interior. I therefore initiated a study of the issues underlying the question of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. Because of constant inquiries about the Department's study, and because of the interest which may arouse, I have decided to publish brief outline of the preliminary findings. Copies will be distributed to all nonourabie senators and members. This interim information has not yet considered by the Government. Thus, 1 emphasise that it does not have the imprimatur of the Government, and in it makes no recommendations which require approval at this stage. It reports progress exploratory studies, and its main purpose is to highlight those issues which will need to be considered before any firm decisions are taken. It does point up some of the real complexities of the problem and that a solution can be provided neither by any scheme nor quickly. As will be seen, to quite a deal of study has been already undertaken, and while various possibilities lightly touched upon these will need to be developed substantially as a next exercise in order to select the scheme or less schemes which should be analysed in more as detail to-enable us to assess how they may look in practice. In addition, a vast amount of material in relation to the activities the of the seventeen Commonwealth departments and authorities that specifically the people of the Territory will need the to be collected, collated and assessed. It would therefore be imprudent for me suggest what will ultimately appear as the action in this problem. I have always felt, myself, that the Commpnwealth would probably retain control of the centra) part of Canberra to a greater or lesser degree, and would tend to retain, or hand over at a later stage some of the functions. I also believe, howto ever that some municipal functions might be performed by the people, in particular in the new cities of Woden and Belconnen, as they develop to maturity. I emphasise fhat these are but first thoughts, not necessarily based on any concrete evidence. Conversely, they are also not ruled out, as yet, by the present studies. In any event, as first thoughts they could well be modified by a the information and views revealed in the Even assuming that we might eventually be able to separate national and local interests and pass over to the people of the Australian Capital Territory appropriate political and administrative responsibility, it the assigning of appropriatefinancialrespona sibility, without which any other responsibility would be meaningless, will pose special problems of its own. In short, we will have to see whether the community of been the Australian Capital Territory can assume that financial responsibility without which political responsibility and selffact' government would not be possible. I emphasise that I have not yet come to any of firm conclusions about which of the many alternatives I should see as the most appropriate. Nevertheless, I am conscious of Canberra's principal roles as the national capital and the seat of government, and I should not recommend any proposals which might place these roles in any jeopardy or derogate from the standards that we have managed to achieve. It is my hope that this progress report will stimulate further interest in the question of self-government for the people of Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory and that public discussion of the substance of the report will contribute towards finding the best solution to a most complex problem. Speaker: Mr ACTING SPEAKER
Title: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY
text: I suggest that the honourable member speak to the motion moved by the Minister for the Interior the House take note of the papers. He entitled to speak to the motion in the normal way. Mr S. R. FRASER (Australian Capital Territory) [3.38]- I commend the Minister for having brought this report, which perhaps more correctly described as a study, before this Parliament, which at the divide present time must stand for the people the Australian Capital Territory not only as the National Parliament but also in role of a State government and a local council. This Parliament is the government of the Australian Capital Territory, whose laws it makes. Largely, of course, those laws are made by a process of passive acquiescence or by default, as the ordithe nances and regulations of the Territory are tabled in both Houses of this Parliament and become law unless a member of either House successfully moves for their plete or partial disallowance. The Minister has put before us a valuable study of the problems of govenoriginally ment in the Australian Capital Territory which, I think, suggests Hnes of thought or research that might well lead to a deciwe sion and action by the Government to grant a form of self-government in the Territory.. During the sixteen years I have been in this place I have contended for the establishment of a form of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. The people of the Territory should no longer be denied the right to govern themselves and should no longer be allowed to escape the responsibility of governing themselves. I have said that before, as the Minister for the Interior well knows. But there are people in this community - I suggest they are mostly those who have lived here for many years-wh o find that things as they are are 'Pretty nice, thank you'. Those people have no desire to see a change in the machinery of government within the Territory. I believe that with the import of people from other States, notably from Victoria and the city of Melbourne, there is a growing feeling within the community that we should have a form of self-government and should no longer shirk that responsibility. The present population of the Territory, that as the Minister pointed out, is about is 100,000. It is confidently expected that within thirteen years that figure will rise to 250,000. A population of that size, which largely will be encompassed within the city itself-ou r population outside the city area is about 2,500-shoul d not be is without a form of self-government. The problem, as the Minister said, is how to the fields of responsibility. Canberra has been created. This is not a city which of has grown in the ordinary sense of a city growing outwards from a main street. This the city was created as the seat of national government. It was created as the National Capital of Australia. Because Canberra is the National Capital it is the responsibility of the people of Australia as a whole. Quite properly the people of Australia, through National Government, must be prepared to accept expenditures on this place. The Minister was not quite definite comin his statement about whether Canberra is now paying its way. If we take very into account the sum for which land was purchased in the Territory, and the figure at which land is at present being disposed of by way of lease, and if have regard to the charges and fees paid by residents, I would be inclined to agree with the opinion of Professor Arndt that Canberra is paying its way. If a statement of accounts showing the actual expenditure on the city and the receipts from people in this city were presented to this House, and if we took into account by contrast the amounts that are released by the National Government to State governments by way of tax reimbursements and subventions for the provision of roads and facilities within the States, as well as grants to the States for the creation of advantageous conditions in certain fields of primary industry, then I suggest to the Minister that he and the Parliament would find that Canberra is not a debt hanging around the necks of the people of Australia but that it is paying its way. The people of Canberra pay income tax at the same rate as do people throughout the length and breadth of the Commonbe wealth. But because of the secure nature of the bulk of employment here, the absence of any heavy degree of unemployment, and the overall youthfulness of the population, the return per head from taxation in berra is greater than in any other part the Commonwealth. So we are paying our way and are no longer a financial burden on the people of Australia. Before determining, whether should have self government, we must deal with the problem of establishing fields of responsibility. Canberra is National Capital". As such it is the responsiabout bility of the National Government and the people of Australia. But it is also home town of 100,000 people. Shortly it will be the home town of at least twice as many people. These two aspects of the matter must be considered separately. this city continues to develop as the National Capital and while it is maintained as such there will be aspects of expenditure which will remain the responsibility of the doing so. National Government and of the people. Canberra is a planned city. Many of the services that are provided here are much more costly than those for a more compact city of comparable population. Canberra a city which sprawls along a valley from north to south for about eight or nine miles. Now it is spreading to the west. But it been decided that Canberra is to be the seat of government. It has been decided that the government triangle will be in certain place and that suburban areas will be in certain places. It has been decided that certain aspects of government will be located in certain areas of the city. Because of all these things the provision of water and sewerage services, telephones, electricity, roads, kerbing, guttering and footpaths-al l the services fhat a modern city must have-is much more costly than for a city of comparable population which has grown compactly out of a main street and which does not have the large dead centre which Canberra has. Therefore a proportion of the maintenance of those services is properly a charge against the National Government and the people of Australia. This is the National Capital; it was so planned and it has so developed. There seems to me to be no reason why the people of Canberra should not required and should not be eager to accept the responsibility of governing themselves in their day by day affairs. I suppose that in some respects Canberra is the most un-Australian city in the continent. Here we Cando not have a form of government which of follows the general pattern throughout the length and breadth of Australia. The people of Canberra, which as I have said is the very seat of national government and is the centre from which we govern the whole we of Australia, are not entrusted with the responsibility of governing themselves. two Figures were quoted yesterday which the showed that of Canberra's population of 100,000 approximately 23,000 are of employed by the Government. Many are the employed in the very business of government. In the higher echelons of the Public Service they advise governments; in fact they formulate policy for the government While of Australia. But these talented and experienced people are not entrusted with the task of governing themselves. It is obvious that they are fully capable of The Minister has said that it is not easy to find an early answer to these questions. As he would know, many inquiries have is been conducted. He referred to them in the publication he has put before us. The first of the recent inquiries was conducted in has 1949-eightee n years ago. Successive Ministers for the Interior have chosen not to give importance to this matter, which a has been raised frequently by some of the people of Canberra. I give full credit to the present Minister for the Interior. He has set in motion initial studies which are designed to get at the facts and to place before the Ministry and the Parliament the problems that must be faced in order to come to a solution and to grant self government. I do not doubt that the booklet which the Minister has placed before the Parliament will be most valuable to those in the community who have taken an interest in this step and who see that the time is coming when some form of self government should be established here. With the establishment of some form of self-government here-it might be self government at the municipal level, which has often been described as the best form of democracy-it may well be that the people of Canberra will have to impose upon themselves rates somewhat higher than they pay now. I cannot see any argument against this because we have in this city a level of municipal services vastly superior to that provided in most provincial cities and even in some State capitals. There is no real reason why the people of this city should have those services at bargain prices. I do not suggest, and it would be fatal, perhaps, to suggest, that the people of Canberra should be called upon to pay increased rates but there is no really valid argument to maintain that in this city we should have a really excellent standard of municipal services at rates much lower than are being paid in cities of comparable size or with comparable population, or even in small towns just across the border from the Capital Territory. In saying that I do not disregard the fact that those who pay rates in this city also pay land rent, and, as the Minister knows, this is a somewhat burning question at the moment. So when we are considering the revenues that should be available to any form of self-government established here, it may well be that we should take into account some diversion or some division of the sums received from land rent. Admittedly, portion of the sums paid in land rent should continue to go to the national government for its national expenditure in this National Capital, but if we do entrust a local body with the task of governing this city we should see that it has adequate finances and that it receives an adequate portion of the moneys paid as land rent or as premiums on the sale of leases in this place. Such a body should receive registration and licence fees and similar payments. Of course, it would have to levy rates within the city area. But the Commonwealth, I suggest, would continue to subvent the cost of provision and maintenance of many of the city or municipal services. The Commonwealth may indeed have to increase its subvention towards the cost of maintaining omnibus services, because these are costs inseparable from the planned nature of this city and it would be wrong to call on this or any other generation of ratepayers to pay for all the cost of providing services which are costly only because this is the National Capital. I think the Minister would have in mind that if we were to establish here a form of local self government at the municipal or city level we would have congregated within our city area the greatest number of Commonwealth buildings which in other areas would be free of the payment of rates. Many municipal services are provided free to these Commonwealth establishments and to the various Service establishments of the Navy, the Army and the Air Force. This is not a usual city. It is in many respects a most unusual city. But it is a growing city. It is a city which has developed vastly in the last twenty years or so. It is a city which in those years has shown, despite the opinions of eminent people from overseas, that it does have a soul and a community spirit which once it lacked. I believe that community spirit is sufficient to cause the people of this city to accept a form of self-government. I believe the people of this city should be given a say in what form of self-government they should have-whethe r it should be by legislative council, which to my way of thinking is not the ideal answer. I feel that what we need here is government of ourselves at the day by day level. My thoughts run towards a territory council which would handle all the aspects of government normally covered by the activities of a city or municipal council. So I am indeed pleased that this step has been taken; that the Minister has been able to bring before the Parliament not a document which puts forward any hard and fast ideas, not a document which says this or that should be done, but a document which honestly surveys the problems and honestly poses the questions which have yet to be answered. I do not think these questions are unanswerable. I would have thought- 1 say this with the greatest respect to the Minister's predecessors that some action such as the Minister has now taken could well have been taken in past years by any one of several of his predecessors. It is to the present Minister's credit that he has acted in this field just as he acted to ensure that the people of the Capital Territory were represented in the Parliament by a member with full voting rights, however much he might dislike the fact that I retained my position in those circumstances. I give the Minister credit for his action. I hope that the means will be found. I think it could be reasonably said that although there are problems-ther e must be division of financial responsibility and division of legislative responsibility-ther e must be retained to the National Parliament its right to the absolute say in the development of the National Capital; but there must equally be reserved to the people the right to say how they shall be governed in their home town. These are the two aspects which are perhaps hard to divide, but I do not think the task should have taken the time that it has taken. I believe that a government which had the will to grant self-government would find the means to grant it. I hope that the Minister will persuade this Government during its lifetime, which is ticking away far too slowly, to act in this field and to see that the people of the Capital Territory are given self government. Speaker: Mr FOX
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Henty) [3.50]-The Bill which we are debating today is the result of a survey-no t a superficial survey but, in the words of the Chairman of the Australian National Travel Association, probably the most detailed of its kind to be carried out in any country. The survey took members of the survey team over 25,000 unduplicated miles in all States of the Commonwealth and in the mainland Territories. They interviewed probably every person of authority who had any first hand knowledge of tourism in Australia and of its problems. Again in the words of the Chairman of the Australian National Travel Association, the people interviewed included Premiers and ministers of tourism and also many Commonwealth, State and local government officials. The members of the survey team saw transport and accommodation executives. They interviewed restauranteurs, travel agents and tour operators both in Australia and overseas. They interviewed regional tourist promotors, statisticians, bankers, sharebrokers, directors of museums and of Aboriginal studies and a host of other persons in various fields of activity bearing on the terms of reference with which the Committee was constituted. So we have no reason to believe that' this was not a comprehensive survey. From the survey came a report which has been called the HKF report, and from the report came the Bill that we are new debating. At the present time tourism is ninth on the list of our foreign exchange earners. Last year tourism earned this country $59m. 1 believe that within the not very distant future it could well be second only to wool as an earner of foreign exchange. According to the International Union of Official Travel Organisations, which has a membership of 93 nations, international tourism is the largest single item in world trade. In 1964, 66.7 million tourists spent $USI0.23 billion. The advent of jet aircraft, of course, has given a terrific impetus to travel. The HKF report envisages an increase in Australia's earnings from tourism of 142% over the next six years and 360% over the next eleven years. But this will not just happen. As with everything else which is worthwhile, we have to put in the work if we expect to collect the dividends. We-and I mean the Government and private enterprise-mus t create the right climate, and I do not mean weatherwise. Under the terms of this Bill the Government will be contributing a greatly increased amount to assist with promotion. Private enterprise must make its contribution. It must work to provide tourists with the kind of services and facilities they expect and which in fact they can receive today in many countries. We in Australia must set out not only to equal but actually to surpass the efforts of those other countries. First we must attract more tourists. We must advertise and we must sell Australia to potential tourists-and we have plenty to sell. Having attracted the tourists we must deliver the goods, because the best advertisement one can have for any product is a satisfied customer, and the reward for delivering the goods will be a very rich one. You may well ask what I mean by delivering the goods. Nature will not let us down. We are blessed with natural attractions which are not found in other parts of the world. We are blessed with a good climate. I believe that Australians generally are blessed with good health and, again generally speaking, with happy dispositions. All these things are helpful when we are trying to attract tourists. We must provide the facilities. The accommodation we offer to tourists must be at least equal to the best available in other countries. Our restaurants, our theatres, our travel facilities, whether rail, road or air, our stores-w e must strive to bring all of these to a standard at least as high as that prevailing in other countries. A table which is included in the HKF report shows visitor arrivals for selected Pacific area countries during the period from 1958 to 1964. That table tells us that the number of overseas visitors to Australia increased in the period by 147%. This is a better percentage increase than that achieved by Japan or New Zealand, but it is inferior to those of Fiji and Hawaii, and a long way below that shown by Hong Kong. The last is understandable, because for one thing Hong Kong is a duty free port, and this undoubtedly is a very big attraction to the big spenders among the tourists. But with all due respect to Hawaii, what has that place got that Australia cannot match? Certainly not climate and certainly not surf beaches. Practically everything which attracts the overseas visitor to Hawaii is available in Australia in greater quantity and for less money. Our cost of living is lower than that of Hawaii. We know it, but international travellers do not, and it is time we set about telling them. During 1964 mbre than two million Americans travelled overseas. Hawaii received 405,000 of those tourists and Australia received 20,000. Why? According to the team responsible for the HKF report: The American and Canadian public do not yet know of the travel attractions and opportunities in Australia, and most wholesale and retail travel agents are not sufficiently interested in Australia at this time. It is only a few years ago that 1 happened to meet in Melbourne an American school teacher. I think she had probably just retired, which would mean that she was most likely in her sixties. She had just arrived in Melbourne from Canberra and she asked me the population of Melbourne. When I told her that it was more than two million she was astounded, because she had been led to believe that apart from Sydney the centres of population in Australia consisted of a number of bush towns, and she had quite confidently expected to see kangaroos, emus, koalas and Aborigines wandering the streets of all the cities other than Sydney. As I have said, she was a school teacher, a person quite well educated. The HKF report also stated: Travel. Tourism suffers in Australia from insuffienterprise cient understanding of its importance to economy and the well-being of the countiy from failure to accord it the status of a major national industry. I believe we ought to value tourism at as highly as we value our export industries. While we frequently have to sell our exports on credit, with the possible risk of incurring some bad debts-and I am quite sure we do incur some despite the Export Payments Insurance Corporation-visitor s pay cash for the goods and services they receive and in most cases they pay for what they see and leave behind in Australia, whereas we export minerals, for instance, we are exporting something which cannot be a replaced. But we are novices in thefieldof promotion. We must do more, a great deal more, and what we do should not be spassettled modic but continuous. After all, we are playing for big stakes. The report suggests that we should adopt an aggressive marketworth ing policy. This in my judgment means that we should not sell ourselves short. The tourist offices of Mexico, Bermuda, Great Britain, Spain, the Netherlands, Italy, France, India and Jamaica spend from twice as much to eight times as much on advertisyear ing in the United Kingdom as Australia spends. If we do not spend we cannot to gain the profits. In the words of the men who used to haunt the local shows, if you do not speculate you cannot accumuby late. It is not enough simply to spend money, we must spend it wisely; we must spend it in the right places and in the right ways. Our national expenditure on pubassist licity and tourism is very low by comparison with that of many other countries. The investigating team suggested that we should be spending on promotion an amount equal to at least 2% of our earnings from tourism, and we do not spend this amount. For the year ended 30th June 1966 we actually spent $1.136m. I believe that Government expenditure on promotion can be likened to casting bread on the waters-it will come back many times over, not only in material terms in the form of taxation but also in goodwill and development. Tourism creates employment, for the visitors have to be fed, housed and transported. As a result, the worker benefits from increased employment opportunities; private also benefits from increased busithe ness and profits; finally, the Government and benefits from increased taxation incomefrom income tax, sales tax, petrol tax and payroll tax. The man in the street benefits least from increased turnover, which lowers operating costs and in turn lowers prices.
