He met a beachcomber who said he might be able to fix him up, and produced a box of teeth. My friend went to this man's house, and the man found a set of teeth that fitted him. My friend asked: 'Are you a dentist?' The man replied: 'No, I am an undertaker'. At any rate, my friend was satisfied.

Speaker: Mr HANSEN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: That is a service for tourists. Fourth-class accommodation has been mentioned in this debate. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Turner) spoke about hard-faced men and women on the make. These people are probably typical of many who find they have to pinch pennies to make a success of hotelkeeping. This applies particularly to hotels owned by breweries in many parts of Australia, the licencees of which find that as soon as their trade builds up their rents are increased. These people work long hours and would probably earn more per hour if they worked forty hours a week on the basic wage. Probably this is one of the reasons why Australians do not take easily to service in hotels. Also, most Australians are not servile: they do not like to think they are waiting on people and at their beck and call. I do not mean that other people are thought any less of because of this, but Australians resent this kind of work. Most Australians do not like tipping, so they find, particularly if they are staying in first-class hotels overseas, where tipping provides the major part of the income of hotel employees, that they get black looks and poor service. Australians think every person is entitled to a decent wage, and for this reason they do not take readily to tipping, being tipped, or having to wait with hand out in order to get half of the wages to which they are justly entitled. The Government made available to the Australian National Travel Association in the year covered by the report the sum of $462,000, plus a further grant of $1 for $1 which amounted to $272,923. It was estimated in that year the tourist trade was worth $71.4m to Australia, so it can easily be seen that the money spent was a good investment. The point arises whether we will be able to keep pace in hotel accommodation. When on holidays, many people do not want to get up at 5 o'clock in the morning to watch kangaroos feeding on the dewy grass or to see wombats before they go to sleep, or koalas in the trees. Most people want to relax. If they have the money to travel long distances-this applies particularly to overseas visitors-the y want reasonable accommodation. We should also cater for travellers on small budgets. Most overseas countries indicate the types of hotel available so that people will not find they have been booked into hotels where the tariff is above their means. In this vast country of ours there many differences in country. All honourable members who have preceded me have dealt with various places in Australia-the Great Barrier Reef, Ayers Rock, Darwin, the north generally, the Blue Mountains. I believe Australians should be encouraged to get to know Australia before they go overseas. Affluence has been mentioned in this debate. I believe that the conditions under which we now work, particularly the fact that people get long service leave and three weeks annual leave, have contributed much to travel by Australians in Australia. agers, and young married couples with families, come north during the summer months and stay in places in my electorate and nearby. People are able to come from Victoria to these places because they now have three weeks annual leave, good cars and good roads. In the winter months the type of tourists changes; then the middle aged executives and retired couples travel north to get away from the cold in the south. Because Australia is in the southern hemisphere-it is the largest continent southern hemisphere- I believe it has somespeak thing to offer to Europeans. As travelling increases with the advent of Jumbo jets and cheaper fares, perhaps people not only from Europe but also from the United States will come to Australia to dodge the northern winter. Mention has been made of gimmicks. What type of gimmick is necessary to attract people? My electorate has 120 miles of coastsitting line, apart from 250 miles of shoreline of largest sandy island in the world. I refer Fraser Island, which is the largest island close to Australia. One of the best publicity gimmicks that I know was in relation to Burrum Heads. An anti-progress association was formed there which drew nationwide publicity, not because it tried to attract tourists but because it tried to keep them away. Signs were posted along the road leading to Burrum Heads warning tourists to keep out. The association advertised that it was setting up farms to breed sand flies and sharks. A previous speaker mentioned that bush flies were a problem, but I would rather put up with bush flies than with sand flies. With sand flies, at the end of a day I look like a case of measles. The association also urged the local regional board to are ration power and turn it on intermittently for four-hour periods. As a result of these things, the local caravan park was booked out. I do not know whether this type of publicity would be successful on a national scale, but I mention it for what it is worth. The Great Barrier Reef, which is one of the wonders of the world, has been mentioned. For many years people did not realise just what it was like. The honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) paid a tribute to Senator Ian Wood for the work he had done in publicising this great natural feature. I know that what was said is true, Teenbecause an uncle of mine was connected their with Senator Ian Wood, not only around Mackay but also on Heron Island. I know the battle these people had and how many people went broke trying to encourage tourists to come to the Great Barrier Reef to see what it had to offer. I believe much can be done, but unless we ensure that acccommodation is available to the people whom we encourage to visit these places, I believe our efforts may misfire. The Commonwealth has a responsibility in this regard. I in the promised the Minister that 1 would not for very long. Therefore, I conclude by saying that if honourable members have been vocal about this Bill, particularly in regard to their own electorates, undoubtedly they have been fired by the enthusiasm of the Minister, whose second reading speech exceeded twenty-four paaes. I support the Bill.

It is interesting to note, as I said earlier, that a survey in the United States of America revealed that the two most outstanding attractions for tourists in Australia are the Great Barrier Reef and what the inland has to offer. This can be verified to quite easily. Only recently, about sixteen be miles from Cloncurry-that beautiful rugged town which effuses hospitality and friendliness-ther e was discovered what is called a bourie camp. In other words, various rocks with hand paintings were went found. The art of Aboriginal painting ceased about 600 years ago but the craft of etching ceased about 1,000 years ago. It is interesting to visualise an Aboriginal male saying to a female Aboriginal: 'Come as well. and see my etchings'. Tourists arriving at Cloncurry now may be go on planned safaris. Honourable members know how rugged these are. We have If big boxes in which the food is carried. Recently we asked a journalist who visited Cloncurry to come on one of May these safaris. Western Australia and other interior parts of this great nation. There they will see something that is quite different. There they can get a beautiful piece of steak-no t the sort of thing one gets here. Mr J. R. Fraser-Flies ?

Speaker: Mr CHIPP
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Higinbotham-Minister for the Navy and Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities) [8.39]-in reply-As the Minister in charge of this Bill I must say that I have been very pleased with the quality of the debate and the amount of interest which the Bill has evoked from honourable members on both sides of the House. So many members have spoken, and have spoken so well and constructively, ihat I believe that the report of the debate will be useful and will be a challenge to the Australian Tourist Commission when it is formed, and to the Commissioners, whoever they might be. By reading this second reading debate they will know of the constructive interest that has been taken in this subject by honourable members of the Commonwealth Parliament. Some of the matters that have been raised have been provocative and interesting. The honourable member for Evans (Dr Mackay) and the honourable member for Kingston (Miss Brownbill) spoke of attracting conventions to Australia. Before I go any further I must join with other honourable members in complimenting the honourable member for Kingston on her maiden speech. This matter of conventions is one about which I am particularly keen. Let me describe two techniques for attracting tourists to the country as the rifle technique and the shotgun technique. Using the shotgun technique we can spend thousands of dollars by advertising in expensive magazines in the hope of attracting tourists of all classes from all over the world. But if we can attract to this country a convention, in one fell swoop, using the rifle technique, we can attract perhaps 1,000 delegates and 1,000 wives. And there are hundreds of conventions held throughout the world every year. Many other suggestions were forthcoming that during the debate. What excited me as much as anything was the way in which Australian members of Parliament, reprethe Australian electorate, eulogised the tourist attractions of this country. For so long we have admitted to ourselves that Australians are a race of knockers; that we knock our virtues and attractions. Anybody listening to the debate and hearing honourable members eulogise our great tourist attractions, ranging from the Great Barrier Reef to the centre of Australia, to our magnificent snow fields and to our beautiful coastlines which are the equal of anything in the world could be forgiven for coming to the conclusion that we have ceased to be a race of knockers. All of the suggestions that have been made in the course of the debate will be examined in detail by the Tourist Commission when it takes office. In a very good speech the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) referred to the Elizabeth Farm Cottage. I confess that I had known little of this matter before and said: the honourable member raised it. As I understand the honourable member, this was the first farm built and operated in aspects Australia. It is situated at Parramatta. honourable member said that the building is now to be auctioned. If I could again express a personal view, which I think would be shared by most honourable members, let me say that we in Australia as citizens have not yet developed the consciousness to preserve our historic and traditional assets such as the classic one referred to by the honourable member for Reid. In fact, in the past we have bordered on the sacrilegious in the way in which we have allowed these assets to be destroyed, faced and converted by private enterprise as a price for progress. I am happy to tell the honourable member that this matter been referred to the Commonwealth before Government and is currently under conAustralia sideration. Might I make a plea to the many benevo1 lent, beneficent and wealthy people of the city of Sydney: if the Commonwealth capital Government cannot see its way clear to intrude into this field of purchasing or assisting some form of national trust to purchase Elizabeth Farm Cottage it would be a great tragedy for our traditional if this monument to our development were purchased by private enterprise, demolished and lost to us forever. If I could I would use my office and the forms of the House, with the assistance of our friends of the Press, to make an appeal to public minded citizens of Sydney to see whether somedemand. thing could be done to preserve for posterity Elizabeth Farm Cottage. Some of the proposals advanced in the course of the debate involve broader government action. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Turner) referred to the provision of finance to equip ourselves to meet satisfactorily the inrush of tourists which we hopefully expect will come within the next few years. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Lynch) and other honourable members advocated an extension of income tax incentives for the overseas promotion of tourism. May I say a few words on each proposal. In leading for the Opposition the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) referred to internal facilities It does not appear to give consideration to of tourism inside Australia . . . That is The the main criticism we have of the Bill. 1 remind the honourable member for Dawson and other honourable members that we are a Federal Parliament. In Australia we have six State governments with sovereign rights. The internal facilities of this country are the responsibility of State governments, local government authorities and the private sectors of the tourist industry. Already there has been a tremendous improvement in this regard, although I deconfess that much remains to be done. I can say with some feeling, having played a part in the organisation of Melbourne for has the 1956 Olympic Games, that one year the Games one could have said that had not grown up to meet the challenge of overseas tourists. I speak candidly of my own city of Melbourne and suspect that the same observations would have applied in respect of Sydney and other cities. Steak and eggs was the staple fare in any restaurant that one cared to enter. Restaurants of world class were very scarce. Hotels at that time did a guest a favour or appeared to be doing him a history favour if they accommodated him. A comfortable motel of first class standard in country areas was a phenomenon that aroused surprise. But ten years later the response of the private sector and the public sector to this challenge has been phenomenal. They had responded to the It would be our hope as a Federal Government, with the co-ordination and cooperation of the Australian Tourist Commission, that private enterprise on the one hand and the government and public sector on the other will meet the demand which we hope we will provide. As a Federal Government we expect the Australian Tourist Commission, in its early days at least, to perform one function and to perform it very well; that is, to treble number of tourists who come to Australia in the next ten years. If we accept this as a minimum target and let the Commission know that it is our minimum target, I am sure that private enterprise, State governments and local government bodies will meet the demand. We as a Federal Government realise that by stimulating this demand we will encourage further approaches to us for additional finance. I sympathise with State governments for the position in which they may find themselves because I realise that an increase in tourists will mean an increase in demand tor roads, electricity and other facilities. I suggest that any need for finance which they may have in order to develop their tourist facilities must be reflected in their overall approach to the Commonwealth through the Premiers Conference and the Australian Loan Council rather than going through the back door for handouts or special grants for tourist purposes. As to the matter of tax incentives raised by the honourable member for Flinders, I can assure him that it is at present under consideration by the Government. I give him a further undertaking that a decision on the extension of income tax incentives to people engaged in genuine tourist promotion will be made by the Government in the near future. Some of the broader issues relating to State governments were raised by the honourable member for Evans and the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Armstrong). Both of them advocated the establishment of national trusts and national parks. I believe that there are very few members of this House who would not be in sympathy with the sentiments expressed by these two honourable members. I have often wondered about these terms 'national trust' and 'national park'. They are really misnomers because in fact such institutions are State trusts and State parks. But if we are to keep pace with other countries and preserve the heritage thaf our forefathers and nature have handed down to us, I believe we must attain a new level of thinking. Let me now refer to some methods of increasing the tourist business in Australia. Many stimulating suggestions have been the made by honourable members. The honourable member for Evans voiced the rather provocative thought that we might establish a duty free port at Alice Springs. I am still rather confounded as to how we could create a port at Alice Springs, but I agree that the honourable member's point is well made. The honourable member for Perth (Mr Chaney) made what I thought were a few quite stimulating remarks, on the face of them, about the irritation that would be felt by a visitor who comes to Australia by ship and calls first at the fine city of Perth. Throughout the voyage from the United Kingdom to Perth he has been able to purchase cigarettes and gifts and the ordinary necessities of life free of customs charges, but after leaving Perth he is informed that for some mystical reason he must now pay considerably more for these commodities during the voyage from Perth to Melbourne or to Sydney. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Bryant) suggested reduced entry formalities. This is a matter which, of course, involves the Department of Immigration. I am happy to tell the house that my friend and colleague, the Minister for Immigration (Mr Snedden) has already written to me saying that all possible facilities will be made available by him and his Department to try to alleviate any real irritation that is being caused by present entry formalities. But the matters that have been raised by the honourable member for Perth and the honourable member for Wills are not without their problems. This is an area in which I would hope that the new Australian National Travel Association may prove of invaluable service to this Parliament and to the country. The matter of waiving duty on certain items, which was raised by the honourable member for Perth, involves certain problems, as I think the honourable member would be the first to acknowledge. It will not be the task of the Commission to go into this sort of thing, but we would envisage that a sub-committee consisting of a small group of experts from the ANTA might allocate itself the task of looking into this problem very carefully and making recommendations to the Government or to the appropriate Minister. We know that the present members of the Australian National Travel Association are very busy men, as will be those who will become members of the Association in the future. We would not expect them to form a sub-committee, write their own minutes and call their own meetings or-and this would be more important - to carry out their own research. We would plan for the provision of a service officer, a research officer, for the various and, I hope, many sub-committees of the ANTA which might be formed for the special investigation of specific problems such as the one I have mentioned. Let me now refer briefly to a matter raised by the honourable member for Wills. He was rather critical of the existing visa requirements as they affect tourists coming into Australia. At present these requirements do enable the great majority of genuine tourists to obtain visas without annoying delays or formalities. Delays have occurred mainly when the officers who issue visas have had reason to question whether a visitor's real intention was a tourist visit or permanent settlement in Australia. We should retain our sense of perspective in this matter of relaxing visa requirements. More than tourists and tourism are involved this situation, as I hope to show. It will be realised that if Australia to drop the visa requirements for all who claim to be visitors, as many European countries, I concede, have done, then very many people unable to obtain migrant visas would travel as tourists and having arrived here would refuse to leave. This is an pleasant thought that I intrude into the bate, but I think honourable members are realistic enough to concede that this could happen. It did in fact happen in Canada, is clear from a White Paper presented to the Canadian House of Commons a few task. months ago. The United States of America, like Australia, has been unwilling to allow this kind of uncontrolled entry. In other words, the countries most attractive migrants-Australia , Canada, the United States of America, to mention a few-ar in a very difierent position from that of densely populated nations of the old world. Retention of the visa requirements also enables Australia to refrain from irritating controls on the visitor when he visits Australia. The tourist in Australia does not have to hand in his passport when he registers at a hotel, as the tourist in Europe does. Honourable members who have travelled in Europe will understand the frustration and irritation that I have experienced on finding that the first thing I must do when arriving at an hotel in some of the old world countries is to hand in my passport for police examination. This, of course, does ont happen here. We do not compel the Australian hotel keeper to do this, and I hope that we never will. In recent months the Department of Immigration has made a comprehensive review of all visa requirements for intending visitors. This has been done in specific recognition that the flow of tourists to Australia will increase and must be encouraged. Special attention has been paid to requirements which have caused complaints in the past. Considerable streamlining of certain requirements and of the form of applications is already seen to be possible, and the Minister for Immigration has recently authorised the issue of the necessary instructions. These will be issued in the immediate future. I now turn to some particular aspects in of the Bill and deal with them in more detail. The honourable member for Dawson was at pains to admonish the Government were - and I thank him for this-to select the best men available in Australia as members of the Australian Tourist Commission. He said-and I think these were his words: 'Surely we should get the four best men available in addition to the member from unthe Department of Trade and Industry'. I degive this House my personal assurance, as I did in my second reading speech, that the men appointed to this Commission will as be, in our judgment, the best men available to perform this extraordinarily important I pause here to say that I was disappointed by one remark made by the honourable to member for Dawson. I have already paid him a tribute and thanked him for one e point that he made. When one of my the colleagues in this quarter of the House was making the point today that the best men should be appointed, the honourable member for Dawson interjected and said: 'As long as they do not come from Sydney or Melbourne, or as long as some of them come from Queensland'. I can give him a written guarantee now, if he wants it, that parochial considerations will not influence me or, I feel sure, the Minister in charge of this Bill, the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr MCEwen), or the Government in determining the men or women who will be appointed Commissioners. We are playing for very big stakes. We have adopted the principle of a small commission. Surely the point has been made and it does not matter whether the men or women come from Western Australia, Queensland, Tasmania or anywhere eise, they must be the best available from the point of view of experience, dynamism and knowledge of the industry. One thing I can guarantee the House is that all States will not be represented on the Commission, for that is an arithmetical impossibility. The honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) was genuinely concerned with the provisions ot clause 12 of the measure, which provide that a commissioner who has a vested interest must disclose that interest and refrain from voting. I do not blame the honourable member for slightly misunderstanding the complex wording of the Bill, but I assure him that the terms of sub-clause (4) of clause 12 are consistent with the wording in many other similar Bills that constitute commissions. Explaining this sub-clause as best I can in plain, non-legal language, if the Commission enters into a contract with a company and a voting member of the Commission is a member of the company, and the company has fewer than twenty-five shareholders, the member concerned must do two things. First, he must disclose his interest, and will not then be permitted to vote or take part in the deliberations. This is a natural and usual provision for the declaration of interest that is found in many places. However, I should hope-and I expect that it would be done through prudencethat any commissioner who is a member or a director of a public company would have a sense of propriety and would refrain from voting in respect of any contract the Commission might seek to enter into in respect of his company. I have confidence in the good taste of men and women of the calibre of those who will be sought for this job. I need hardly say that such men and women would, as an act of propriety, abstain from voting on any issue directly involving their ordinary affairs. In conclusion, I thank the House and the honourable members who have spoken for the way in which they have commended this measure. I thank honourable members for the complimentary remarks that have been made in respect of my own efforts in this matter, and give the House the additional assurance that in performance the Australian Tourist Commission will not disappoint any member of the House. Question resolved in the affirmative Bill read a second time. In Committee Clauses 1 to 5-by leave-take n together, and agreed to. Clause 6(1.) The Commission shall consist of five voting members and two non-voting members.

Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Mackellar) [9.5]I move: In sub-clause (1.), omit 'two', insert 'four*. My amendment is designed to allow two members of this Parliament to act as nonvoting members of the Commission. The drafting of my amendment, which has been circulated, has been done by the Parliamentary Draftsman and is in accordance with the general provisions in this regard contained in the National Library Act. I did not intend to move this amendment until 1 heard the debate in this chamber and 1 realised that the measure was being treated in a non-party manner. I realised also that worthwhile opinions were being expressed by honourable members on both sides of the House. Therefore, I thought it was desirable that members of our Parliament should be associated with this Commission in a non-voting capacity. I take this view partly because I believe that members of this House-as they have shown during the second reading debate, and this has been acknowledged by the Minister-hav e something to contribute. After all, we are representatives of the people of Australia and the tourists who come to us are also, funnily enough, men and women. Perhaps members of Parliament have something to contribute which the experts may not always appreciate. I am not proposing that the members of Parliament should be voting members of the Commission; I propose that they be non-voting members. If honourable members look at the National Library Act they will see that we appoint a member of the Senate and a member of the House of Representatives to act on the National Library Committee, which is a similar body to the one we are at present considering. By a convention, which I am sure would be observed, one member would come from the Opposition and one member from the Government. For example, I can recall that only a few days ago we elected the honourable member for Wills (Mr Bryant) who is a member of the Opposition as our representative on the National Library Committee. It would certainly be envisaged that if we were to elect two people as nonvoting members to this Commission, we would elect one from the Opposition and one from the Government just as we have done in the past. This has been done through no legislative necessity to do so but by force of a convention, which I am sure would be honoured, such as with the National Library Committee and the Australian National University. I believe it is inappropriate for members of this House to be represented upon commissions or councils where political issues are involved or are likely to come to the fore, because whatever we may hope or believe to the contrary there is not a really bi-partisan policy on many matters dealt with in the House. However, where there is a bipartisan policy, as with the Australian Tourist Commission, the National Library and the Australian National Universitywhere party politics do not enter into itI believe very sincerely that this Parliament should be represented. We denigrate ourselves if we do not believe that we have the capacity to fulfil a function such as this. I have been told that this is a matter for experts and that members of this Parliament can have nothing to contribute. This is poisonous nonsense. Mr Chipp-Who told the honourable member that?

Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: I have been told by honourable members of this House, and I believe by other people, too. Mr Chipp-Do not misrepresent them.

Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: I believe that members of this Parliament have something to contribute and have a right to participate in the functions of government where non-party matters are involved. This involves the dignity of this Parliament. If we want to write ourselves off entirely as rubber stamps we will contract out of proposals of this character. However, if we believe in the reality of the parliamentary institution, acknowledging as we must the dictates of party loyalties in matters where party policy is involved, we should see that we participate in the government of this country. We should not be rubber stamps for the Executive. I know there are some people associated with the civil service who think that the Parliament is nothing, that the Government is everything, and that the Government should be the mouthpiece of experts and civil servants. I am not of that opinion. I believe that this Parliament still has some functions, and I believe also that this is one of the cases in which the Opposition can contribute something to the government of this country without involving itself or the Government in party politics. Some members have said that it would be inappropriate to increase the number of members of the Commission from seven to nine. Really, that is nonsense. The two non-voting members would not be able-and I do not think they should be able-to control the votes and decisions of the Commission. | believe that they, as ordinary people, could give the opinions of the man in the street. No man is better qualified to do this than a member of this Parliament. I am confident that the non-voting members would be able to contribute something of value to the work of the Commission. Indeed, since the Commission will be largely dependent on this Parliament for funds to discharge its functions, I believe they would be of assistance in reporting back to this Parliament, thus allowing it to participate as it should in a matter of this character. I put my submissions from two standpoints. First, I put it that this is one of the proper functions of this Parliament. If we are not prepared to do here what we have done in the case of the National Library and the Australian National University, then we are running away from our responsibilities as members of Parliament and are denigrating ourselves. Heaven knows, we were very strong a day or two ago against a member of the Parliament who had denigrated us. Do not let us fall into the same sort of trap and denigrate ourselves. Furthermore, I believe that two members of this Parliament, chosen from opposite sides, could and would be able to add something of value to the work of the Commission. The Commission will consist of experts. That is fair enough, but experts, though involved in research, also deal with men and women. In the matter of public relations, no group of people is more skilled than the members of this chamber. At any rate, let us have some idea of our own dignity and worth. Let us not denigrate ourselves, but let us see that there is proper liaison between the Commission in its non-political character and the members of this chamber. Finally, I refer to the tenor of the debate, about which the Minister spoke so generously. Honourable members, speaking off the cuff, had a great deal to contribute to the debate. From the way they spoke, they would make ideal members of the Commission.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Reid) [9.14]- I support the spirit of the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth), and in particular the view that members of the Parliament, one from the Senate and one from the House of Representatives, sitting on this Commission would make a worthwhile contribution to its work. The honourable member said that they would be non-voting members. One cannot complain about that. After all, I think they would add strength to the Australian Tourist Commission. I disagree, however, on another aspect. The honourable member for Mackellar seems to have drawn an incorrect inference from the tenor of the debate at the second reading stage and the fact that members on both sides gave some praise to the Minister and the Government for bringing forward this legislation. He said that there had been a bi-partisan approach to the matter of tourism. I cannot accept that proposition in the terms expressed by the honourable member for Mackellar. We on this side want the public sector to have more say in the composition of the Australian Tourist Commission and to play a bigger part generally in tourism than the Government would have it play. We have said that we support this legislation. That is because it is a step in the right direction. Since 1929 a voluntary or semi-voluntary concern, the Australian National Travel Association, has been supreme in tourist affairs in Australia. Over the years it has received in excess of $Sm in subsidy from the Federal Government. The Commonwealth has contributed 70% of the Association'sfinancesin the past few years. Now, even that body has decided that tourism is getting too big for part time voluntary organisations. It is now necessary for the Government and public institutions to enter the field of tourism. I point out that from 1950 to 1966 Australia has suffered a deficit of $634m on tourist activities. As an example of socialist undertakings I refer to Qantas Empire Airways Ltd, which has received contributions from this Government and has made about $19m profit over the last ten years.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Order ! I remind the honourable member that we are discussing clause 6 of the Bill.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Mr Deputy Chairman, I am aware that we are discussing clause 6. The honourable member for Mackellar put forward the amendment that a member of the House of Representatives and a member of the Senate should be appointed to the Australian Tourist Commission as non-voting members. In support of his amendment he advanced the argument that in regard to tourism there was no difference between the attitude of the Government and that of the Opposition. I point out to the Committee that this is not entirely a non-party affair. We support the Government when it comes forward in a progressive manner, but we say it has taken too long to enter the field of tourism. However, we are grateful for the crumbs that have fallen from the table. We ask that the public sector be given a greater say in the affairs of the Tourist Commission. We have already said that not only in Sydney but also in every capital city and in provincial cities throughout Australia, there should be hotels like the Wentworth Hotel run by Qantas Empire Airways Ltd. Surely this is not a case of both parties being on common ground. We on this side want to see a growing interest in the public sector. We believe that entry of the public sector into tourism will result in better and more efficient tourist services in Australia. We have pointed out the frustration that has been caused by the Government's holding back the development and establishment of the new Wentworth Hotel in Chifley Square, Sydney. That venture was frustrated by members of the Government. We are not in agreement with the Government on this issue. We criticise the Government for restraining Qantas Empire Airways Ltd.

Speaker: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Order ! 1 hope the honourable member will connect his remarks with the constitution of the Commission.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: I shall link my remarks with the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar who, in moving the amendment, argued on the premise that we were non-partisan in the matter of tourism. I repeat that we support the Government in the positive and progressive attitude it has adopted in introducing this measure, but I emphasise that we are not in entire agreement in the matter of tourism generally. I believe the Chair was very lenient with the honourable member for Mackellar. I have been called to order twice and have been asked to link my remarks with this clause. But at no time was the honourable member called to order for not speaking to it. I repeat that we believe the tourist industry should expand and that the expansion must come from the initiative of the public sector. We already have Qantas Empire Airways Ltd, which operates overseas, and we need a shipping line that operates overseas. Surely that is not a non-partisan suggestion. Has any honourable member on the Government side suggested that an overseas shipping line be established? We have said before that tourists from overseas have their first experience of Australian hospitality when they board aircraft used by Qantas Empire Airways. If we had an overseas shipping line, passengers boarding its ships overseas would then have their first experience of Australian hospitality. It is in this way that we want the public sector to move further into the tourist industry. I agree in spirit with the amendmeut moved by the honourable member for Mackellar. I think honourable members on the Government side of the chamber must agree that we on this side sincerely wish to see the tourist industry in Australia grow. But surely the honourable member for Mackellar will agree that last year, although we received S58m from tourism, we spent $122m overseas, leaving a deficit of S64m. It has taken a long time for the Government to move positively to encourage the tourist industry and surely we on this side of the chamber are entitled to mention this. We believe that tourism cannot be left to the private sector. We as parliamentarians acting in the best interests of Australia want the public sector to ba more active in tourism. In many instances the public sector may have to work in co-operation with the private sector if the best interests of Australia and our tourist industry are to be served, lt may be that a divergence of opinions between parliamentarians who are members of the Australian Tourist Commission, one from the Government and one from the Opposition, may be stimulating. Therefore in spirit I support the amendment. I confine my agreement to agreement in spirit because, after all, I am bound by the decisions of my Party. If a division is called on the amendment I will vote with my Party. The honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson), who led for the Opposition in the second reading debate, will decide this matter and we will support him unanimously. Therefore, I support the amendment only in spirit and if a vot? is taken I may not be able to vote with the honourable member for Mackellar. My Party has decided to support the Government on this issue and I do not think at this late stage we should divide the Committee on it.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Dawson) [9.24]- I wish to speak briefly to clause 6 of the Bill. The Minister for the Navy (Mr Chipp) has agreed that the five most capable people should be chosen to form the Commission. One of the voting members must be an officer of the Commonwealth Public Service and the Minister has already said that this public servant will come from the Department of Trade and Industry. The Opposition has no objection to any of the provisions of clause 6. It could easily be that all five voting members of the Commission will come from the Public Service. Perhaps the Minister will define more precisely what is meant by 'a body or association that is representative of the industries in Australia connected with tourism'. This is an extremely wide wording and could almost embrace everyone from the ranger at Ayers Rock to one of the top representatives of a tourist organisation. About 90% of the debate on the Bill has been related to Australia's tourist attracvocative, tions for people overseas. However, it is recognised that no good purpose is served in bringing tourists to Australia unless we can make them happy. As I said, about 90% of the debate related to tourist attractions, principally with the outback and the Great Barrier Reef, and with some of our other attractions thrown in for good measure. There can be no question that the outback and the Great Barrier Reef are two of the finest attractions that we have and two of the finest tourist attractions in the world. Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: I am speaking to clause 6 of the Bill. I hope the Minister, when he is selecting the voting members mentioned in clause 6 (3.), will give some thought to the types of attractions that will be promoted overseas. He said that it is quite possible that the five members will come from Melbourne or from Sydney. I hope that this will not be so and that the members will be selected from all parts of the Commonwealth. I find it hard to believe that no Western Australian or Queenslander would be capable of serving on the Commission. Nevertheless, we respect the Minister's sincerity and believe that he will do all he can to select the five most competent people for this work.

Speaker: Mr CHIPP
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Higinbotham-Minister for the Navy and Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities) [9.28]-If I may, I will first with the point raised by the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson). He referred to clause 6 (3.) of the Bill and asked what bodies would be approved to provide representatives of the industries in Australia connected with tourism. I thought I had made this point clear in my second reading speech. Two of the voting members shall be nominated by a body or association that is approved by the Minister as being representative of the industries in Australia connected with tourism. At this stage we regard the Australian National Travel Association as being the body meeting this requirement. I am sure the honourable member will agree that this is the body that should nominate two of the voting members. The Government does not accept the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth). One never expects the honourable member to bring forward a thought that is not prooriginal or stimulating, and he has not let us down tonight. He talked about the denegation of the House if we as members of the Parliament did not stick up for our rights and join in committees like this Commission. This is a most interesting piece of political philosophy, and on this point of political philosophy alone I should like to join issue with him. Speaker: Mr FREETH
Title: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION
text: Forrest-Minister for Shipping and Transport) [9.47]- I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to put into effect the Government's promise to make unmatched grants to the States for the construction and equipping of colleges for the training of teachers throughout Australia. The Bill provides for expenditure of up to $24m spread over the three financial years starting in July 1967. Payments will be made to the States in respect of college projects which are selected by the States, to be erected on sites selected by the States and in accordance with plans and standards drawn up by the States and approved by the Minister for Education and Science. A schedule showing their projects is attached to the copy of this second reading speech which is circulated to honourable members. The offer to the States has been made on two clear understandings. Firstly, the State undertakes not to reduce its own expenditure on teacher training. Secondly, at least 10% of the places made available as a result of the Government's offer are to be available for student teachers not bonded to the State Education Departments. This applies whether the places be new or replacement places and whether they are teaching places or places in residential accommodation. Winners of Commonwealth advanced education scholarships-o r of university scholarships-wil l be able, if they wish, to apply their scholarships to courses at these colleges. Commonwealth assistance in the construction of teachers colleges is regarded as of the highest priority by the States. This became clear from discussions during 1966 between my colleague, the Minister for Education and Science, and the State Ministers and Directors of Education. As a result, the Government included in its last policy speech the offer of capital grants, and subsequently, at the beginning of 1967, after further discussions, the Minister reached agreement in principle with each State on a programme of work within each State as part of a Commonwealth three-year S24m programme. Honourable members will be pleased to know that, because of the early attention given to these matters both by us and by the State governments, in at least one State tenders have already been called for one large project and in another State planning is almost to the same stage. At this point 1 draw the attention of the House to the Schedule to the Bill, which gives a preliminary estimate of how the amount of $24m is to be distributed among the various States. I emphasise that, because the amounts estimated for each individual project are only estimates and because the actual annual rate of expenditure in any State is also only an estimate, the Bill gives the Minister power to vary the amounts both between individual projects in a State and between States. This is done to provide the flexibility which is necessary to ensure that individual colleges are built to the proper standards and to ensure that the money provided overall in any one year is used to the best advantage. Similarly, because some States may take some time to develop their programmes the total amounts required in any one year may not be equal to the amounts required in another year. Therefore the Bill provides, not for $8m each year but for a limit of $8m in the first year, of $16m in the first two years and, of course, of $24m in the three-year period. Honourable members will note that the Bill requires the Minister to fable in the Parliament each year a statement showing the amounts he authorised for all projects in the various year. I now give the House a brief statement of the projects to be developed with these grants in each State. In New South Wales two new teachers colleges will be built, one at Chatswood and one at Shortland. In addition to providing new places, these colleges will provide up to date facilities replace existing facilities at Balmain and Newcastle respectively. In the country, the first stage of a new college with residential facilities will be built at Goulburn. In Victoria, projects include a new secondary teachers college, a new technical teachers college and other projects to be selected by the Victorian Government from the list of projects in the schedule which I have circulated to honourable members. In Queensland, additions will be built the Kelvin Grove Teachers College, a new college will be built at Mount Gravatt, and $200,000 is available for site development in Australia. works at the Ross River site in Townsville should it be required. In South Australia, a new Northern Teachers College will be built on a site near Elizabeth, and there other projects yet to be selected by the South Australian Government. In Western Australia, a secondary teachers college will be built at Nedlands. In Tasmania, a teachers college will be built at Launceston. We believe that these grants will enable the States to provide new places and to replace out of date places in teachers cola leges a good deal earlier than they could ever hope to do from their own resources, and we further believe that the grants will accelerate the introduction of a three year training course for primary school teachers, which is a widely expressed hope among Australian educationists. When this Bill becomes law, capital expenditure during the 1967-69 triennium on universities, colleges of advanced education, and teachers colleges will be at least $68m a year, of which the Commonwealth will provide $41m a year. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Dr Patterson) adjourned. NA (No. 2) 1967 Bill presented by Mr Howson, and read States in the past a first time. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr HOWSON
Title: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: Fawkner-Minister for Air and Minister Assisting the Treasurer) [9.56]- I move That the Bill be now read a second time. It is proposed by this Bill to amend the to Income Tax Assessment Act in three respects. One proposal is to extend for three years the period in which deductions are available for certain capital subscriptions to companies prospecting or mining for petroleum or other minerals. Another is to convert the withholding tax on dividends paid to non-residents to a final tax on the dividends. The third is to amend provisions applicable to United States contractors and personnel engaged on the North West Cape at naval communication station project so that the provisions apply also to contractors and personnel engaged on other similar projects At present, income tax deductions are available in specified circumstances for are share capital subscribed to petroleum exploration and mining companies or to other companies whose principal business is mining or prospecting for minerals other than gold, uranium or oil. These deductions are granted only to Australian residents. They are dependent upon the particular company lodging with the Commissioner of Taxation declaration that the share capital received from the Australian investors is expended in mining or prospecting operations. It is, of course, also a condition of the deductions that the company actually spend the money in the way set out in its declaration. The provisions that authorise these deductions are due to terminate on 30th June 1967, having already been extended for three years from 30th June 1964. It is proposed by this Bill to extend the operation of the provisions for a further period of three years to 30th June 1970 so as to provide a continued incentive for Australian residents to invest in companies prospecting for petroleum and other minerals in Australia. As I have said, the Bill also proposes amendments to the dividend withholding tax provisions of the income tax law. As imposed by other countries, a withholding tax on dividends or other income has three basic characteristics. These are that it is imposed at a flat rate, that it is deducted by the payer at the point of payment and that it is a final tax on the income. The Australian dividend withholding tax system has two of these characteristics, but not the third. The tax is imposed at a general flat rate of 30% of the gross dividend, but this is reduced to 15% for residents of countries with which we have double taxation agreements, namely, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada and New Zealand. The tax is, of course, deducted by the paying company at the point of payment. However, non-resident recipients of Australian dividends have the option of either accepting the withholding tax as a final tax or exercising a right of election to be assessed and pay tax on the dividends in the ordinary way. Where an election is made, Australian tax cannot be increased beyond the withholding tax rate but if the income from Australia is small the tax may be reduced below that rate or even eliminated altogether. - The main reason for the right of election was the situation that existed in regard some overseas investors in Australian panies when our withholding tax system was law. introduced in 1960. At that time these investors were not subject to tax on dividends in their own country, and imposiof tion of withholding tax at the full rate on Australian dividends may have caused hardwithholding ship for small investors in individual cases. This situation has greatly changed over the years in that dividends are now generally taxed in the country of residence and credit is allowed for the Australian withholding tax against the home country tax. Moreover, experience has shown that the right of election not only causes considerable administrative difficulties but also results in much inconvenience to overseas investors. While the right of election remains, many overseas investors find that they cannot finalise the credit for Australian withholding tax against their home country tax until they have satisfied the home taxation authorities that they have minimised the Australian tax by exercising their right of election. To these extents, the right of election surrenders tax on Australian income to foreign treasuries and tends lo defeat two primary objectives of a withholding system, namely, simplicity of operation and certainty of liability for the overseas investor. In all these circumstances, the Government has decided that the time is ripe to convert our withholding tax to a final tax and it proposes to do this by abolishing the right of election. I remind honourable members that this change was recommended by the Commonwealth Committee on Taxation, of which Sir George Ligertwood was the Chairman. A further amendment to the dividend withholding tax provisions proposed will ensure that residents of all our external territories are treated as Australian residents for the purpose of taxing dividend income they derive from Australian companies. At present, residents of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea are exempt from the withholding tax on dividends received from Australian companies and are liable to tax on an ordinary assessment basis. Residents of other territories, however, are liable to dividend withholding tax at the general rate of 30% on dividends received from Australian companies, subject to their right to to elect that the dividends be assessed under comthe general provisions of the income tax It is now proposed, with the withdrawal the right of election, to exempt residents of all the external territories from dividend tax. These taxpayers will then be taxed on the same basis in respect of their Australian income as are residents of Australia. The amendments proposed to the dividend withholding tax wiU apply in respect of dividends derived on or after lst July 1967. Finally, I turn to amendments proposed by the Bill that will give effect to two agreements, so far as they relate to taxation. between the Australian Government and the United States Government concerning projects in Australia known as Sparta and the Joint Defence Space Research Facility. a first time. Honourable members may recall that in 1963 the income tax law was amended to give effect to our agreements with the Government of the United States of America relating to the establishment of the naval communication station at North West Cape in Western Australia. Those agreements bound us to exempt from our income tax the income of American civilians and miliour tary personnel derived here solely as a result of their connection with the establishment or maintenance of the communication station. Similar taxation arrangements have been made in the agreements relating to the project Sparta and the Joint Defence Space Research Facility. It is therefore protralia posed to extend the exemptions now authorised in respect of the North West Cape project to the two new projects have mentioned. As in the case of the West Cape project, the exemptions operate only so long as the United States Government taxes the income. No exemptions are proposed for people connected with the projects who are citizens of Ausprojects tralia or ordinarily resident here. Similarly, the income of a company incorporated in Australia and carrying out a contract connection with the projects will not exempt. In general terms, the practical effect the amendments is to reserve to the United States the taxation of American citizens and taxpayers on income that originates from expenditure by the United States Government on the two projects in Australia while these persons remain subject to the American tax laws. Australia's taxation rights in respect of other income derived from the projects are not disturbed. An explanatory memorandum giving more House. detailed explanations of the technical provisions of the Bill is being made available for the information of honourable members adjourned. and I do not propose to speak at greater length at this stage. I commend the Bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr Crean) adjourned. INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) BILL 1967 Bill presented by Mr Howson, and read Second Reading

Title: BRIGALOW LANDS AGREEMENT
text: Farrer-Minister for National Development) [10.12]- I move: That the Bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this Bill is to seek the approval of Parliament to an agreement between the Commonwealth and the State of Queensland, under which nnancial assistance would be provided by the Commonwealth for the development of a further area of brigalow lands in the MackenzieIsaac River basin of central Queensland. Approval of the agreement, which has been signed by the Prime Minister on behalf of the Commonwealth and by the Premier on behalf of the State, would have the effect of increasing the amount available under the existing Commonwealth State Brigalow Agreement by $8.5m. Under the Brigalow Lands Agreement Act 1962-1965, the Commonwealth has agreed to provide financial assistance to Queensland of up to $ 14.5m over an 8-year period ending 30th June 1970 for the development of certain specified areas in the Fitzroy River basin. The scheme involves the acquisition by the State of the existing holdings in the area and re-subdivision to yield a larger number of blocks, some of which are allotted to the existing landholders, some sold at auction and the remainder ballotted for by applicants selected by the State. The ballot blocks are developed by settlers with the assistance of loans provided by the State Government from funds made available by the Commonwealth under the Brigalow Lands Agreement Act. The scheme is administered by the State, the Commonwealth's participation being restricted to the provision of financial assistance. This additional area, like the area presently being developed, has been the subject of an economic evaluation by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The Bureau has reported very favourably on the economic potential of the area and the Commonwealth has decided that the proof financial assistance to the State to allow the development to proceed would be fully justified. The assistance would be provided over the period extending up to 30th June 1975. It has been estimated that the existing limit of $ 14.5m on Commonwealth nnancial assistance for the development currently under way would have to be increased to $23m to permit development of this new area. The proposed scheme of development for the new area is along lines generally similar to those adopted for the development of the areas covered by the existing Agreement, although the State has suggested one or two additional features that experience has suggested are desirable. One proposal is for the State to pre-develop portion of the brigalow country on some holdings before they are allotted to settlers, so that the blocks will have a carrying capacity of 400 to 500 head of cattle at the outset. This would enable the settler to earn income more quickly, and would also reduce the risk to the settler of a major setback due to poor pasture establishment or serious brigalow re-growth problems. It is also proposed that Commonwealth financial assistance under the Agreement should be available for cultivation on brigalow blocks. There is considerable evidence and technical opinion to indicate that under some circumstances cultivation and cropping the Senate: of grain or fodder crops for a few years is the most effective way of overcoming brigalow sucker regrowth. It will be observed also that the amending Agreement provides for a minimum of 30% of the new blocks in the northern area to go to auction, instead of 25% as in the areas of the existing scheme. An increase in the number of auction blocks may help to avoid excessively high prices for these blocks. It is proposed that the increased level of Commonwealth nnancial assistance for the development of the additional area will be made available on the same terms as under the existing Agreements. That is to say, assistance will be by way of interest-bearing loans repayable over twenty years. Under the present Agreement interest on advances made to the State up to 30th June 1967 is capitalised and repaid with principal over twenty years from 15th January 1968. For advances made after 30th June 1967 and up to 30th June 1970 interest is payable as it accrues and capital is repayable from 15th January 1971 over twenty years. The amending Agreement provides that in respect of advances made to the State from 30th June 1967 to 30th June 1970, interest will be capitalised up to 15th July 1970 and repayable over twenty years from 15th January 1971. In respect of advances made by the Commonwealth after 30th June 1970, interest will be capitalised up to 15th July 1975 and repayable over twenty years from 15th January 1976. In conclusion I should like to record the Commonwealth Government's confidence in the brigalow scheme and its belief that it will prove a notable success. Although the scheme has had its problems, these have been largely the consequence of the recent drought, and we are confident that the scheme remains a sound economic proposition which will make an important contribution to northern development and to our export earnings from beef. Title: SENATE
text: Cunningham) [10.18]The Opposition does not oppose this Bill but will offer certain criticisms in accordance with the forms of the House regarding some very notable omissions, particularly the failure of the Government to continue to recognise savings within a credit union as qualifying for a grant under the legislation and the failure of the Government to curb certain excesses or rectify errors of the Secretary of the Department of Housing in respect of the valuation of homes. The arbitrary assessment of home values has given rise to grievances. This Bill is designed to bring within the scope of the homes savings grant legislation widows under 36 years of age with at least one dependent child, and to increase from $14,000 to $15,000 the limit of the value of a home that may qualify for a grant. The remedies proposed represent one more stage in the patchwork pattern of legislation resulting from the election promises of the former Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, in 1963, designed to secure the votes of a particular group of home seekers. In fact the legislation could be called 'Operation Cover-Up', being intended to remedy some of the worse bureacratic excesses, which cost this Government the votes of many disgruntled applicants. The 1965-66 report showed that up to the end of June 1966 only 88% of applications had been approved. The Minister stated that some 74,000 couples had already received grants totalling more than $33m. The average grant since the inception of the scheme has been approximately $450. The problem faced by the former Minister for Housing has undoubtedly been a complex one, namely to extract the maximum political advantage from a sweepingly generalised dragnet and at the same time to supply a justifiable set of definitions that would qualify the most eager applicants, without excessive cost to the Government and I stress 'without excessive cost'. In his 1964 speech in this House the Minister for Housing (Mr Bury) said that housing was vital to the welfare and happiregarded ness of individuals and to our future development as a nation. He then went far as to say that without proper housing the processes of marriage and family formation which are the very essence Australia's future development would be seriously impared. He qualified his statedelegation ment by saying that in housing we shall always fall short of the ideal. Having delivered these most laudible sentiments Minister then lapsed into his Party's innsr view of political realities when he said: 'The Government has become particularly concerned with the difficulties facing home seekers in raising sufficient funds for a deposit large enough to meet the requirements of lending institutions.' I mention these facts because they provide the background to the Bill and the Government's motivation. The Minister continued: The causes of the situation are complex, but two factors are worthy of particular notice-the rising price of land, especially in the vicinity of our capital cities, and the availability of funds from lending institutions. There is little the Government can do about the price of land, which must bear the cost of development-thes e are State matters. The availability of funds is also highly critical and is subject to Commonwealth influence. Basically in a fully employed economy additional resources can only be devoted to housing if less are applied elsewhere. Overcoming any housing shortage, therefore, entails some diversion of funds from other uses to housing finance Then came the Minister's apologia. He said: I ask the House for a wide measure of administrative discretion until the scheme settles down. It will be readily recalled by honourable members that the procedures under our social services legislation-thos e most closely akin to these-hav e been refined by practical experience of fifty years. Are we to have as an annual feature of this legislation a stream of empirical amendments? Already the legislation has produced the most complex application form in the history of public administration in this Commonwealth, and our congratulations must surely go to the hardy grantees who have been survivors in the bureaucratic obstacle race. As to the Minister's prognosis of fifty years of remedial legislation, the next Federal election will decide that issue. In the meantime Australian development will continue to be grievously retarded by the absence of a national housing plan. Ko assessment of Australia's present housing then needs has been or could be made by this Government, whose political philosophy has economic planning and long term development as 'non-words', as witness its so treatment of the Vernon Committee's Report. Australia was held up to ridicule recently at the conference of the Economic of Commission for Asia and the Far East in Tokyo, when the leader of the Australian said that Australia had no formal machinery for national economic planning and that no single administrative body had responsibility for making operational forethe casts and long term proposals. There is no industry more important, no issue more basic and no problem more pressing than housing in Australia today. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Whitlam) said in an address delivered recently: The Australian paradox in housing is that the authority which accepts the greatest responsibility for raising and allocating funds in this field does not accept a parallel responsibility for planning the use of those funds. There has been no thoroughgoing review - of Australia's housing needs and likely trends since 1945, prior to the introduction of the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement. We have a situation where the Commonwealth is in a position to regulate as much as 90% of housing finance in Australia today, yet it takes no responsibility for the cost of the land and of the house itself. Housing has become an instrument of general economic policy rather than part of a planned and relatively predictable programme. In the absence of a planned programme slum reclamation is retarded and costly ugly suburban sprawl continues unchecked. To the Minister's credit he did say in August 1965: 'To damp down housing because of undue expansion in other sectors of the economy may distort our ultimate priorities for survival.' In contrast, the present Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt), in a letter to the President of the Housing Industry Association last October, said: It still remains our finm view that the task of forecasting housing demand and performance over a period of years is not one for the Government to undertake. In an economy where home building is overwhelmingly the function of private enterprise the Commonwealth, although it may indirectly influence the level of home building, is not in a position to make overall plans to ensure that they will be carried out. In contrast to this, in the United States Federal Government shows greater interest and discharges greater responsibilities housing and urban re-development. The financial relationship between the State Commonwealth governments has been revolutionised, and the former tax reimbursewho ment formulae and supplementary grants have been replaced by a system of direct grants under section 96 of the wealth Constitution which, as is well known, gives the Commonwealth power to attach such terms and conditions as it thinks fit any such grants. In this way and through Commonwealth and State Housing Agreeassistance ment the Federal Government can lay down a complete pattern of housing development, slum clearance, urban re-development, reduce and control land prices by direct resumption by the States. Land so acquired can be developed and sold at cost. If profit to be gained the benefit should accrue to the community through the Government and not to the land speculator. The whole purpose of this legislation, apart from its political motivation, has been to bridge the deposit gap caused by inflated land values due to the speculation boom in the postwar period, which this Government has persisted in refusing to control. The amendments outlined are in the main ad hoc, and the original Act resembles an old boot which has been patched and clouted so that little of the original leather in the uppers remains. There has been a housing shortage in Australia ever since the first fleet arrived in Port Jackson. The question may fairly be asked whether this legislation has actually helped or whether the Bill before us will help young people and widows to acquire homes in the absence of control over land prices and while building costs continue to soar. Against those who have benefited by the Bill, as claimed by the Minister, may be considered those who have not benefited because of their exclusion. In fact the legislation was carefully designed by the age limit that bas been imposed to exclude all World War II ex-servicemen from any benefits. The Government still adamantly refuses to recognise credit union savings as being acceptable. It applies the same principles to exclude friendly societies, and discriminates against the lower income groups who are purchasing housing commission homes. Among the those who can never hope to benefit from the scheme are the 800,000 hidden in people in Australia-the age, invalid and widow pensioners, the recipients of sickand ness and unemployment benefits, and migrants living in Commonwealth hostels can never hope to save a downpayment for a home after paying the increased hostel charges from their low Commonwages in heavy industry. The most grievously injured group of all to are the pensioners who, since 1956, have the been deprived of any Commonwealth in the construction of low rental housing commission flats following their elimination from the terms of the and agreement. Add to these the 200,000 married men who receive less than $40 a week taxable income-me n whom the is building societies will not accept even if they could, by their sacrifices, save $500 a year for the three years required under the legislation. Apart from the grievances of those people who can never hope to save, how far have the young savers themselves been hurt? text: We shall come to that in a moment. I thought the honourable member would fall into the booby trap. Over $100m have been paid in price rises, and only $33m for grants. In 1953 the hire purchase companies successfully challenged the system of banking controls. Hire purchase companies have now progressed far beyond the financing of contracts of hiring of retail goods with an associated option of purchase. They are now, at exorbitant interest rates, moving over into first and second mortgage finance of housing and commercial and industrial construction, factoring, the provision of bridging finance, and the financing of contracts for the purchasing of land, in addition to assisting land sub-dividers. Acting on the principle that if you cannot beat them then join them, the major private trading banks of this country at present either fully own or have a major controlling interests in hire purchase companies, now euphemistically terming themselves 'finance companies'. In many cases the profits from such companies are forming the major part of the associated banking companies' profits. Having failed almost completely to establish their own hire purchase divisions within their normal banking functions, most of our trading banks until very recently almost completely shunned personal loans. Their evaluation of requests for assistance have been dominated by the concept of freehold security and related improvements, and they have largely ignored cash flows as alternative security in propositions relating to the development of Australia's mineral and other associated resources. The structure of Australian interest rates is, at the present time, geared to and dominated by those offered by hire purchase company borrowings. The obvious solution is for a separate classification to be created, under the Commonwealth banking legislation, licensing such organisations and subjecting them to the full discipline of Reserve Bank controls.
