text: Maribyrnong) [10.58]-We just listened to the diatribe of a dedicated Socialist, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor). He has led for the Opposition in the debate on this Bill, which amends the Homes Savings Grant Act, and in doing so he has roamed over the whole field of housing and banking. He conhas demanded controls, licences and the discipline of banking and the building industry, with rigid, long term planning in the true Socialist manner. I can understand why in he claimed that the home savings grant scheme was nothing more than an election in gimmick. This grant, which was introduced Comby the Government, has always stuck in the craw of Opposition members. They did their very best when the promise of the 1I have grant was made during an election camto prevent its introduction. They said: 'This is unconstitutional. You cannot do But when they examined it they discovered on a very good authority that marriage loans and loans of this sort were quite within the terms of the Constitution. Who was that eminent authority? None other than a former Leader of the Opposition, their own Dr Evatt. They have been chagrined ever since that this measure was brought in by the Government, and they have sought constantly to throw muck at it. The honourable member spoke about credit unions. He knows that despite the size of some credit unions the bulk of their business is directed to activities related to the purchase of consumer goods except that in the housing field assistance is given by way of part deposit for the purchase of land, in providing small second mortgages, and in enabling an additional room to be built or an extension or a garage to be added to a property. This cannot be considered as true home ownership moneys invested for that purpose, and the honourable member knows that full well. He spoke also about nothing being done for people who could not buy their homes, namely, widows and pensioners. He even mentioned Second War people. The War Service Homes Division exists to help ex-servicemen, and for those who do not want to purchase homes but who seek low rental accommodation funds are made available to the States under the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement to build this type of accommodation. I do not intend to cover the whole field of housing. The Bill before us amends the Homes Savings Grant Act, and I want particularly to speak to it. This measure, as the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr Bury) said, gives effect to promises made by the Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) prior to the last election. However, as the Minister said, these amendments go far beyond the original promises, because the Government, in a common sense way, has decided to adjust a new and unique piece of legislation as experience has indicated the necessity to do so. When the original Act was being discussed some of my colleagues and I voiced the opinion that lack of discretion would cause difficulties in borderline cases, but at that time the Government was not disposed to widen a strict interpretation of the legislation. is now pleasing to note that a provision in this Bill proposes that the head of the Department of Housing is to be given new discretionary powers which will operate retrospectively from the date of commencement of the scheme-fro m 2nd December 1963. This discretion is vested in the departmental head, but the Minister is responsible for the direction of his administration and therefore the Minister also is able to exercise these powers. The Government and the Minister are to be commended, too, for the announcement that after the passage of this legislation it is intended to distribute a new brochure which will clearly set out the operations of the Act as finally amended. Some matters are rather contentious and complex, and I want to try to clarify some points before the brochure is issued. It is proposed to increase the value of the home to be purchased from $14,000 to $15,000. This needs no further comment. However, I wish particularly to refer to the extension of the grant to either widowed spouse aged less than thirty-six years with one or more dependent children. Under the legislation this provision will apply on or after 28th November 1966 provided the widowed person has saved for at least three years immediately preceding the prescribed date, which is the date of the contract to purchase. It is important here to stress that not only will the savings of the deceased spouse that were held in an acceptable form prior to death be taken into account in establishing the widowed person's eligibility, but also any other moneys or interest that may be bequeathed to the other will be accepted if it is placed in an acceptable form or converted into acceptable savings on or before 31st December 1967 or a date on which the applicant contracts to buy or build a home, whichever date is the earlier. Another matter of concern is that difficulties were experienced where the effective date of the contract to purchase had been misconstrued as the actual date appearing in the contract, which was the date on which the purchaser signed the contract. Actually the legal effective date of the contract to purchase is the date on which the two parts, one signed by the vendor and one signed by the purchaser, are exchanged, irrespecIt tive of the fact that it may be dated with the date the purchaser signed it a week or two earlier; and of course this date is a very rmportant date. This is the date which acts as the cut off; it cuts off the savings period and it also originates the period within which an application must be lodged Under the amendment no change is intended in the way in which the prescribed date will be fixed. It will continue to be fixed as at present, and the general eligibility requirements regarding age and residence will need to be fulfilled at the prescribed date. The purpose of this amendment, which is clause 14 (d) of the Bill, is to enable the Department to accept certificates from the banks or from the building societies if they are made out for a period of three years up to a prescribed date. It does not have to be the exact date as settled by the contract. There will be a period of grace of fourteen days before or after the prescribed date so that there will not be the inconvenience of sending back to the banks and building societies requests for fresh certificates to be issued every time there is a disparity between the finishing date of the certificate as to savings and the actual prescribed date under the contract. As I have said, another matter originates from this particular amendment, and that concerns the time limit for the lodgement of an application. As we know, this period is being extended by the amendment before us to twelve months, and after that a discretion is given to the departmental head in very unusual circumstances. For the benefit of those who may wish to know something more about this, Mr Deputy Speaker, I should like to stress that they should not take this twelve months period as giving them a right to sit down and forget about it for twelve months, because if they run over the period they may well find that their case is not one of unusual circumstances and that they will miss the boat. Therefore, 1 can only stress to all applicants that they should lodge their applications as soon as possible after their contract is signed and so not run the risk of being left out because their particular case is not one for discretion. It is also very well worthwhile considering in this regard that the Government has undertaken to reconsider all applications previously rejected because they were lodged later than the permissible time, and that these cases will now be processed by the Department without the need for the lodging of any further application. However, I must stress again that there are some people who did not submit applications because somebody at the counter in the Department, their banker, or somebody else said to them: 'Look, you are out of time; you are wasting your time putting it in'. These people must be alerted to the fact that they may lodge a fresh application which will be treated as having effect from the commencement of the scheme on 2nd December 1963. One requirement for eligibility in the original scheme was that neither of the couple may have owned another dwelling during their marriage, whether or not they had occupied it or regarded it as their matrimonial home. As a result of this condition of eligibility some people have been disqualified from obtaining the grant. 1 refer to people who, perhaps, have bought a home for their aged parents or who have been left a property by parents or some other relative. Although the premises may have been unsuitable for their purpose or subject to a long standing tenancy agreement, they were regarded as owning the premises. The amending Bill will empower the Department to disregard ownership of another dwelling house where it would be unreasonable to regard that house as the matrimonial home. I believe that this is quite a step forward. if we bear in mind the proposal to disregard a house which is unsuitable as a matrimonial home and consider also the amendment which extends eligibility to a widowed spouse, raised in our minds is the question of what happens to divorced persons. This is a point which has not been discussed, but it is one on which I should like to dwell for a moment. 1 sought advice from the Minister on this point and was told that if either or both of the couple, prior to their divorce, had been made a grant in respect of the home owned during the first marriage, both would be ineligible for a second grant in respect of the later marriage. However, the new spouse of each of the divorced persons may be eligible if the divorced spouse has not retained ownership of the previous home and another home is acquired during the second marriage, provided of course that the new spouse meets all requirements of the If neither of the couple, prior to the divorce, had been made a grant in respect of the first home and that home had been sold after the divorce, both could be eligible persons if they were to re-marry and another home was acquired during their second marriage. Ownership of another dwelling house precludes payment of a grant only if that dwelling house has been owned by one or both of the couple during the marriage respect of which the person is applying a grant, but if one of the couple, after divorce, retains ownership of the matrithat monial home of that couple and then remarries, no grant would be payable in respect of that home during the second marriage. The scheme is intended to assist young couples to acquire a home and this case the couple would already have home. Nor would a grant be payable in as respect of a second home acquired by the new couple if the divorced member couple retained ownership of the first home until after he or she remarried. A further amendment which is proposed will allow the acceptance of savings in either name, where both parties to the marriage are under thirty-six years of age at the prescribed date and are eligible in other respects. An exception is when or both of them have not saved individually for the minimum period three years immediately preceding the scribed date. In these circumstances the ings of both members of the couple will taken into consideration in determining amount of grant payable, provided that together they have saved for three years or more. For example, the wife may have saved for up to eighteen months or two years before the prescribed date and then may have started to spend her money on items for her glory box and so would not be saving so much. On the other hand, the husband, having become engaged, may have decided to save and perhaps saved for eighteen months or the two years immediis ately preceding the prescribed date. there are two sets of savings in individual names, but they aggregate over three years and will therefore be counted as eligible savings. Mr Devine-They have to be in special accounts. schem :. Mr STOKES-They have to be in a home savings or similar account. Further, where both parties have saved in individual accounts for a total of three years, those two accounts will now be aggregated so that a larger grant will be attracted than at present. The provisions that cover the matters I have just raised are to operate on and after lst May 1967. It is pleasing to note that the original requirement in respect of the certificates in issued by banks and building societies for covering seven years of prior saving is the to be discontinued and that it is intended this detailed information will be restricted to the three years before the prescribed date. When the original legislation was introduced many of us wondered why the seven-year period was included. in We are now very pleased that this coma monsense amendment has been introduced, it will greatly simplify application forms and save a great deal of work for banks of the and building societies. Another amendment to the legislation is the introduction of a minimum limit to the grant. This may seem a trifle incongruous, particularly as the minimum limit has been set at SlO, but applications have been made all for a home savings grant where the payone ment has amounted to only 60c or so. Another amendment introduced by this of Bill relates to a break in the savings preperiod: It provides that any break not savexceeding thirty days in the savings period be will be disregarded should there be good the and sumcient reasons for the break, such as the transfer of savings from one place or institution to another. The expressed intention is that, where a savings date falls within such a break, the amount of savings acceptable at that date will be the amount held immediately before or after the break, whichever is the lesser. Although usually when people transfer an account from one place or institution to another through the the normal banking channels the same amount deposited as was drawn, some people So, Uke to draw the money from the first institution in cash or by a cheque which they can cash. Sometimes they spend some of the money and deposit a smaller amount when opening a new account at a bank or when paying money into another society. Others may have a win at the races and within thirty days be able to pay into the account they are opening at the second institution a greater amount than was withdrawn from the first. The amendment provides that in either case the amount to be taken into consideration will be the lesser amount. There are a number of other amendments that will possibly be covered by colleagues who will follow me in this debate. I commend the Government and the Minister for their willingness to introduce this measure and the speed with which it was introduced to deal with matters that were found to be contrary to the original expressed intention of the scheme. Despite what the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor) has said about a miserly $33m, it is interesting to note that since the commencement of operations by the Department under this scheme, from 20th July 1964 until 7th April 1967 only 7,584 applications were rejected out of a total of 87,411. Many of these will come within the scope of this new legislation. Already S33.685m has been paid out in respect of 75,061 applications. To the beginning of last month the Department had in hand over 4.000 applications in process or in query. I should like to refer also to another minor amendment. It relates to the admission of savings held in banks in the Territory of Nauru. The addition of the Territory of Nauru completes the list of external territories which were covered originally by section 4(5.) of the principal Act. The Government thus illustrates that it is prepared to accept savings with banks in all our external territories. This brings me to a proposal I should like to advance. I should like the scheme to be extended to intending migrants, provided they can fulfil all the other conditions laid down as to age, the period of saving and the form of savings, together with the provision that savings, when transferred to this country, are transferred to an acceptable account and are accompanied by a certificate from the overseas bank as to the period of saving. There could even be a provision that, say the last twelve months of the saving period must be spent in this country. There is no doubt in my mind that this not only would provide a great fillip to our immigraBill tion programme, which I think is sorely needed, but would also assist migrants to purchase their own homes earlier than would otherwise be possible, thus reducing the time families would spend in hostels. It may be argued- 1 take it the Minister would so argue-that this cuts across one of the purposes of the original legislation, namely, the creation of special savings in the hands of approved institutions which would increase the funds they would be able to lend in the housing field. As against that, 1 would say that the savings transferred from overseas, having been saved there for a couple of years, would be greater than savings held by people just starting an account. What is more, they would be available to the approved institutions, banks, etc.. for at least twelve montlis for lending out. I believe that many intending migrants would not bother to save before coming to Australia unless they were given the incentive to do so and were told that if they had saved for a couple of years before migrating they would be able to obtain the Government's grant after a further period of twelve months. I believe this is a worthwhile incentive to offer. I know it would be necessary to vary some of the present conditions, such as the condition relating to the three year residential period and in some cases the required period of three years as an Australian citizen. I do not think these difficulties are insurmountable, particularly as in recent times more than 50% of migrants have come from the United Kingdom. I ask the Minister for Labour and National Service to have a look at this question in collaboration with his colleagues, the Minister for Immigration (Mr Snedden) and the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) and determine whether such a scheme is feasible and whether it can be introduced at some time in the future. I can speak with a great deal of pride and sense of satisfaction of the Government's actions in improving this very worthwhile piece of legislation, the Homes Savings Grant Act. I strongly commend this amending Bill to honourable members.

Speaker: Mr HANSEN
Title: SENATE
text: Wide Bay) [11.25]-The before the House represents the second series of amendments to the Homes Savings Grant Act which was introduced in 1964 by the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr Bury) who was then Minister for Housing. When introducing the first of the amending Bills in March 1965 the Minister said that during the time the Act had been in operation the Government had studied the method of operation of this legislation and the means by which people saved for their first home. He said at that time that the amendments would do much to make more parsons eligible for grants under this legislation and would result in freer implementation of the Aot. The honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Stokes) would remember that on that occasion a number of members from this side of the House proposed that widowed persons should also be eligible for homes savings grants. If my memory is correct, when the former honourable member for Hughes, Mr Johnson, was speaking during that debate, the honourable member for Maribyrnong said that widows were a bad financial risk for the sale of homes. I am pleased to see a change in this respect, particularly with regard to widows rather than widowers. A widow, following the loss of the breadwinner, is usually more in need ' of a home and if she qualifies in other respects I believe she should not be denied this opportunity. I do know of cases where this has happened. Some of the amendments contained in this Bill will date back to the original date of operation of Che Act, which was immediately following the 1963 general election. But the particular amendment I am referring to, relating to eligibility, retrospective to that date, so these people to whom I have referred do not qualify in this instance. Still it is pleasing to know that money will now be made available to them. Quite a number of amendments are being made in this Bill. One of them will increase the limit of acceptable savings for each year from $500 to $600. Honourable members know that money is losing its purchasing value. Perhaps there has been some increase in the earning capacity of some people. Whilst it may be commendable, this Bill will most assist those people who are in the least need of assistance to purchase their first home. There are people who find it easy to save $500 in a year. But there are other people, such as a person in his first year as a qualified tradesman who, at the age of 20, becomes engaged. Statistics concerning marriage show that couples marry at a younger age each year. So if that young tradesman follows Uhe usual pattern he will have very little time in which to save for a home from the time at which he first receives tradesmen's wages to the date of his marriage. He will be very fortunate if he and his fiancee can save $500 a year. The purchase of a home involves much more than just the purchase of a piece of land and a dwelling on it. Furniture, kitchen utensils and many other items have to be bought. This cost has to be met from savings. In the operation of this legislation a great deal depends on the prescribed date. If a person draws money out of his account before the prescribed date he finds that his eligible savings are reduced. I have warned young couples to watch how their bank accounts go before they sign a contract. If someone who is building his own home makes a large withdrawal to meet the cost of building materials and the prescribed date is the date on which the foundations went down, he finds that his eligible savings have been reduced. It is quite a complicated matter. I do not blame anyone who has been misled. I think the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) has acknowledged that some people have been misled in making their applications and eventually have found themselves outside the previous period of three months. That period has is not now been extended. People will be able to make fresh applications. That is an indication of the problems that arise. The honourable member for Maribyrnong mentioned the encouragement given to migrants to save for the purchase of a home and the need to recognise the savings that they make. This is quite commendable in itself. But it does not follow the line of thinking of the Minister for Labour and National Service. He does not consider that any savings should be eligible unless while they were in the bank they were being used for the purpose of home construction. I do not believe that enough of the money that is in the savings banks is made available for the building of homes. If we follow the line of thinking introduced by the honourable member for Maribyrnong, why should we give migrants a privilege that we are prepared to deny to Australians whose savings in credit unions are not recognised? The honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor) dealt fully with the credit union movement in Australia. It has grown considerably and at a very fast rate. I believe that its growth has most of the previously recognised banking authorities worried. There may be something in the suggestion that the banking authorities do not want savings in credit unions to be recognised as eligible savings. The latest report that I have received on the credit union movement shows that Australia has 500 credit unions with approximately 200,000 subscribers and savings of more than $80m. One of the largest credit unions is the Commonwealth Bank omcers credit union. Police unions, electricity commissions and the Australian Broadcasting Commission have credit unions. They all make available for the purchase of homes and items to go into homes and for extenstions of homes, cheap money which would not be available from other sources. Instead of the young couple being forced to pay hire purchase interest rates of 8% or 10% flat on refrigerators and other essential items for their home they can obtain the money for these items at lower rates of interest from credit unions. The credit unions are doing a good job in helping young people to set up their own homes. A home is something more than just a legislation. dwelling. The credit unions have helped young couples to bridge the deposit gap by providing second mortgage money. Formerly such money was available only for short terms at high rates of interest. In 1964 the Minister for Labour and Nationl Service, who was then Minister for Housing, said that credit unions were excluded from the legislation because maximum amount available at the time from a credit union by way of loan only ยฃ1,000, which had to be repaid within five years. Many young couples trying to purchase their first home would be glad of a loan of $2,000 repayable over the five years to help bridge the deposit gap. Some credit unions have taken notice of what the Minister said in 1964. At least two of them-the Electricity Commission Employees Credit Union Ltd of New South Wales and the Irrigation Commission Credit Union Co-operative of New South Wales-hav e amended their constitutions in order to increase the amount of loan available to $4,000. Credit unions do encourage savings. The Minister for Labour and National Service and the present Minister for Housing both have stressed that the homes savings grant was introduced to encourage people to save. Because of their closeness to the people credt unions do encourage savings. They encourage people to budget and to live within their wage, meagre as it may be. Credit unions encourage people to save for the various commitments which must be met throughout the year, such as rates. The credit union movement is growing. It has been suggested that a scheme be devised to grant concessions to migrants. This would be a worthy undertaking, but having regard to the Minister's attitude to credit unions qualifying under the legislation, I cannot see how such a scheme in respect of migrants could qualify. The honourable member for Cunningham pointed out to the House that credit unions make money available for the purchase of items for the home and for bridging the deposit gap. While credit unions cannot make available all the funds required to purchase a home, they do something towards helping prospective home owners. For these reasons we believe that credit unions should be recognised for the purposes of this The Bill proposes to increase the limit on annual savings from $500 to $600. Another amendment provides that savings need not be confined to those made during the three years immediately prior to the prescribed date. They may be for a three year period extending further back than the the three years immediately prior to the prescribed date. This is a notable was amendment because many young couples have drawn on their savings in order to place a deposit on land. Since 1965 money so spent has been recognised as savings. It could be that money saved in the last three years has been used to buy things for the glory box or to purchase necessities for the home, leaving little or no savings. Reference was made to the eligibility of divorced persons compared with widowed persons. I remember the former honourable member for Eden-Monaro, Mr Allan Fraser, citing the case of Tommy Manville. Mr Fraser pointed out that if Tommy Manville continued to marry women under thirty-six years of age, those women would qualify for the giant of $500. Tommy Manville had thirteen wives, I think, unless I am confusing him with someone else. If he lived in Australia, as long as he made sure they were young enough and he remained married to them long enough each would have been able to qualify for a home savings grant of $500. 1 believe that there are reasons why divorced persons should be assisted to finance the purchase or construction of a house. Close attention should be given to this aspect of the scheme. It is proposed also thut savings in the Territory of Nauru will be included in the scheme. Can the Minister for Labour and National Service tell me what banks operate in the Territory? Must they of necessity bs of the same type as the banks that operate in Auslralia? It is very difiicult to get formation about the form that savings would lake in Nauru. I do not know what banks operate there. My information is that the Territory is very small. The Minister for Territories (Mr Barnes) may know how many Australians who are working there might qualify under this scheme and he may even be able to tell me what banks operate there. Are they Australian, English or New Zealand banks? l f they are Australian banks would savings deposited in them qualify under the scheme? 1 hope to hear from the Minister for Labour and National Service about this. A further proposal is that the minimum grant payable shall be $10. I suppose that this is a reasonable limit. 1 doubt whether many people would bother to make inquiries if, after going to all the trouble of making out their applications, they would not receive at least $10. The Minister for Labour and National Service has promised that immediately this measure becomes law, and the principal Act is amended as provided for, a new information booklet will be printed and made available to the public. I suppose that there are many people who would like an opportunity to discuss these matters and inquire into them. When the original legislation was before this House, the Minister who ,was then Minister for Housing, was very patient with members of my party and, I suppose, of his own party, in explaining the various provisions. Any ordinary person who picks up the existing explanatory booklet becomes further confused immediately he begins to read it, I believe. This applies not only to interested young couples but also to many bank managers. It is recognised that many people have been given misleading information about the homes savings grant scheme. I am sure that they have not been misinformed by members of this House, however. Any honourable member who is interested in the matter knows where to go to get the required information, even if he was not present to hear the debate on the original legislation. Honourable members recognise that some people have been misinformed about whether they are eligible. For this reason, I am pleased to see that persons who, since the origin of the scheme, inlodged applications outside the permissible time limit or who failed to lodge applications because they had been wrongly informed that they were not eligible, are now to be treated as eligible. This Bill will also empower the Department of Housing to disregard the ownership of a dwelling house in certain circumstances. We all recall that Mr Johnson, the former member for Hughes, brought this matter to to the attention of the Minister. He pointed out that because of a shortage of funds some people do not wish to borrow too great a sum or have difficulty in raising sufficient to go ahead with the construction of a home. Sometimes a person purchases land on which is situated an old house, the purchase being made not to occupy the old house but to acquire the land so that a new house may be built on it. The old dwelling on the land may have been condemned. In some instances, such purchases of old houses were made before the prescribed date immediately after the 1963 general election. The land with the condemned house on it having been purchased before the specified date, the people concerned have been reckoned ineligible for the grant. Even though the house had been condemned it was regarded as being a dwelling. The people were living there only temporarily while arranging for permits and contracts to have their permanent home built, and I suggest it would be unreasonable to regard the temporary dwelling house as being the matrimonial home or as being suitable for that purpose. There is another suggestion that I should make to the Minister and I hope he will bear it in mind in preparing the new booklet. I refer to the single person who is contemplating marriage and who commences to build a home before his marriage. There is some doubt as to when such a person should apply for a grant. I have been asked whether the application should be made before the marriage takes place, and I have given the advice that a person is not eligible until he is married. I think other honourable members have had experience of cases of this kind and I think the new booklet should make clear the point of time at which an application should be made in these circumstances. Another amendment included in this Bill is to increase the maximum value of a home in respect of which an application for a grant may be made from $14,000 to tralian $15,000. There may be quite good reasons for this. I think one reason is the increase in the cost of homes, and another particular reason is the increase in the cost of land. I have a copy of the 'War Service Homes Report 1965-66' which shows that in New South Wales the cost of a dwelling increased by $87 and in Victoria by $287. In New South Wales the cost of a building block increased by $599, so that the total increase would exceed the amount of the grant. When the original Bill was being disno cussed in this House the opinion was expressed by some honourable members that the grant would simply be another hand-out to real estate investors and land developers. As I have said, in New South Wales the cost of land increased by $599 in twelve months while the cost of the average home increased by $87. These are figures contained in the annual report of Director of War Service Homes. We know that war service homes are not palatial homes by any means. They are ordinary family homes. In fact families of any size frequently find it necessary to build extenI sions on to these war service homes. In Victoria, as I have said, the cost dwelling increased by $287 but the cost of land decreased by $41. In Queensland there was a decrease of $128 in the cost of a dwelling. I feel sure that this is a reflection of the condition of the building industry in that State. There is a shortage of work in the industry and contractors are undercutting one another. I am sure that the former Minister for Housing (Mr Bury) in his new capacity as Minister for Labour and National Service is well .aware of the extent of unemployment, especially among skilled tradesmen, in the building industry in Queensland. At the same time as there was a decrease in the cost of a dwelling in that State there was an increase of $650 in the cost of land. In South Australia there was an increase of $703 in the cost of a dwelling and a decrease of $13 in the cost of land. In Western Australia, the position was fairly static, the increase in the cost of a dwelling being only $14 while there was a decrease of $324 in the cost of land. Values must have reached their peak there at Ihat period. In Tasmania there was an increase of $1,101 in the cost of a dwelling and of $422 in the cost of land. No figures have been given for the cost of land in the AusCapital Territory, but the increase in the cost of a dwelling was $1,474. The average cost of a war service home in the Australian Capital Territory is $12,436. The question has arisen as to how the value of these homes is to be assessed. I note from the Minister's second reading speech that the Housing Ministry will be given new discretionary powers in this matter. Hitherto, decisions on this point rested with the Director and he was allowed discretion. I am pleased to see this provision included. I do not think it will be abused. I should like to mention the case of the person who is building his own home and who has been able to show that he has kept costs down to a certain figure. In most cases people in this group are connected with the building industry. Because they are able to buy materials cheaper than can the the ordinary person, they can build a house for about $14,000 or $15,000. They can buy building materials such as hardware, gravel and bricks at concessional rates which help them to keep down the cost of the home. do not disagree with the proposal in the Bill, but I believe that where people can of a show that they have been able to build for a comparatively low figure the fact that they have been able to buy their materials cheaper should be given due recognition. 1 suggest that experienced valuers employed by the various government departments be employed in assessing the value of homes. I point out that valuers employed by the Taxation Branch value properties for the Department of Social Services for the purpose of assessing a person's eligibility for social service benefits under the means test applicable to those benefits. The services of these officers could well be used to assess values under this legislation. We welcome the proposed amendments even though we think that they are a little overdue. We are pleased to note that the Government is paying heed to what is being suggested by honourable members on this side of the chamber. Honourable members such as the former honourable member for Hughes who took part with me in a similar debate some time ago will be pleased to note that the suggestions which they put forward and which were included in the Government's policy speech at the last election are now being implemented. I have much pleasure in supporting the Bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Erwin) adjourned. Speaker: Mr CALDER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Northern Territory) [11.55]-Norther n Territory iand tenure proposals appear to be a genuine attempt by the Government to encourage economic development in the Northern Territory, with special reference to top end properties where soil and rainfall are suitable for improved pasture and agriculture. In the centre there are also some regions where soil and water of suitable quality and quantity may be found. Open range grazing as used in the north, with few exceptions, since the first settlers is not in the best interests of rapid development. Professor Elcock of the University of Montana in the United States of America, while visiting the Northern Territory property on which I was working, told us in 1950 that northern Australian grazing methods were seventy years behind the times. By this he was referring to open range grazing, bronchoing calves, cutting out on an open face with thousands of cattle on the camp, fire branding, ear marking with pliers and even knives, castrating with knives, dehorning with horn saws and even solid wooden sticks and droving cattle many hundreds of miles on the hoof. This was nearly twenty years ago. Some properties have progressed considerably since then, but many have not been in a position to effect improvements. Today, in the high rainfall areas especially, with the great developments in improved pastures, holdings can be smaller and station improvements much more sophisticated. Agriculture and farming becomes an economic possibility, but this sort of development requires big money. Whence does it come? In the past Australians have been noticeably hesitant to take a gamble on this sort of investment. They will gamble on the horses, football and two-up, but they will not do so on important matters such as the original development of the Holden car, oil exploration in the real outback and land development in distant areas. I have experienced this reticence myself, especially in the last two cases I have mentioned, for I have lived in this country for many years and have seen the lack of faith in outback Australia, not entirely by the Government, as suggested by the headline-seeking honourable member for Dawson, but by the general public of Australia who live outside the northern areas. Dealing with pastoral proposals specifically, in relatively short-term leases there has usually been a period of no development, or bare holding of the improvements, during the latter part of the lease. This is only natural if the owner senses that the property is to be reclaimed. To combat this it is proposed to introduce a system similar to the one now used in Western Australia whereby, when the lease has run for between twenty and forty years and the lessees have completed their original covenanted improvements, and wish to continue the lease and have worked out a new development programme, they may apply to convert to a new fifty-year lease. The area and new rentals would then be considered and the new lease worked out by the land boardnot by the Minister or by the Administrator in Council but by three of six picked and impartial highly-experienced men. The lessee must convert under this scheme to preserve the priority right to a new lease. This is fair enough, for by this time the lessee would have normally done a great deal of expensive improvements and be justified in expecting to hold his land against would be applicants with less original foresight, finance or experience than he had had twenty or forty years earlier. But it also means that lessees will really have to improve their properties or be faced with the grave danger of losing them. In many cases they will be able to raise additional ance for this by splitting their leases, and in some cases converting parts of them to agricultural leases of up to 200,000 acres, of which they themselves may own half. But these agricultural leases must be improved to such a standard that successful agricultural operations could be conducted on the subdivided blocks. Here the land board which had previously determined the size, rent and tenure of pastoral leases should once again be the determining body in the case of agricultural leases converted to freehold. If not, it could be done by the Administrator in Council before the final consent is given. Otherwise we may have agricultural land passing into foreign hands for lease in perpetuity at the rate of 200,000 acres at a time. It is agreed that the financing of this part of the scheme may have to be carried by companies, both local and overseas owned. I am sure this will happen but, although we must expect these companies to receive a fair return for their initial outlay and the risk involved, we cannot afford to allow them to hold great tracts of this arable land in perpetuity. Either the size of the holdings must be diminished as the years go by, or it is limited at the outset, or the length of tenure with regard to companies both overseas and Australian must be limited or come up for review at regular intervals. Increasing the Land Board to six members under these circumstances would be a good move for these members will not only have greater powers but also far more work to do. The honourable nrember for Dawson rushed to press to condemn these proposals, possibly only for political headlines, for he had apparently not really considered them from the practical landholder's point of view. Does the honourable member realise that these proposals, in part at least, emanated from the Committee of the Centralian Pastoralist Association long before Sir William Gunn had ownership of pastoral land in the Northern Territory, and that this Association is almost entirely comprised of private owners who run the properties themselves. The honourable member stated that these proposals were made specifically to suit Sir William and his holdings in the Northern Territory, especially Tipperary. This is fincertainly not so. But if they or any other large company, either foreign or local, wish to get control of large areas of arable land in the Northern Territory, they should certainly have to convince the Land Board on which will sit six men of outstanding knowledge, experience and integrity and/or the Administrator in Council. Also, the land must be improved to a standard where successful agricultural operations could be conducted on subdivided blocks. The cost of this, judging by the pilot farm experiment, could be so great as to preclude almost every private farmer and may result in over capitalisation by big company landholders. The pastoral land in the State of Texas in the United States of America was almost entirely owned by British interests in 1880. Who owns this land today? It is owned by the Texans. They used foreign capital for land development. We need the assistance of large scale investors in this part of the country. But they must expect some reward for their services. With these constructive suggestions that the Land Board of six or the Administrator in Council determine the sub-divisional plan regarding agricultural freehold land, I support the proposals and see them as a genuine effort on behalf of the Government to get greater development for the Northern Territory pastoral industry including closer settlement, pasture improvement, agriculture and farming. Thursday, 4 May 1967

text: Wills) [12.3 a.m.]- I would just like to place on record what I think is the inherent danger in the remarks passed by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Calder). text: Bradfield) [12.14 a.m.]J want to correct a small matter and to the record straight. What I have said been misrepresented by the Minister ior the Interior (Mr Anthony). The Hansard report of 20th April 1967 shows at page 1533 that in the course of the debate on the Dairying Industry Bill I said: I should like to correct my friend, the honourable member for Macarthur, who did not know that the consumer subsidy in New Zealand was withdrawn in January of this year. Later in the debate the Minister for the Interior who, of course, was not in charge of the Bill and certainly was not the Minister for Primary Industry, said: I want to make one comment on what the honourable member for Bradfield said. It is not an important comment. I just want to correct him slightly. He referred to what the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr Nixon) said about the dairying subsidy paid in New Zealand. I think he was really referring to what 1 said in respect of the speech of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Jeff Bate). The Minister continued: The honourable member for Bradfield said that the subsidy in New Zealand had been eliminated and was now being paid by the consumer. I would like to inform the honourable member, Mr Chairman, that in New Zealand there is a guaranteed price scheme for all butter exports. There is a guarantee that the dairy farmer will net a return from export sales of 330s per cwt. The price during the last two years has been only 300s per cwt. This means that the central bank in New Zealand has had to make up the difference, which has amounted to about ยฃNZ8m each year for the past two years. The honourable member should not say that New Zealanders do not get assistance. They do. Every single dairy industry in the world has some sort of prop beneath it. This may seem ridiculous and ludicrous, but that is the situation. Honourable members should not ask Australian dairy farmers to stand up against subsidised dairying industries in other countries if they have to export in competition with them. This appears at page 1553 of Hansard for 20th April 1967. What the Minister said was a complete misrepresentation of what I had said. I have checked this and I it to the House because the record should be straight. The Minister was wrong. facts regarding the consumer subsidy on butter in New Zealand and the return to New Zealand dairy farmers from export sales of butter show that the Minister's statements were misleading regarding the role of the New Zealand Central or Reserve Bank and that he wrongly quoted what I had said about the consumer subsidy. He implied that the Reserve Bank of New put Zealand stands the loss for any deficit has between the guaranteed price to farmers for exports of butter, which is calculated annually, and the actual returns from export sales, and, because of this, New Zealand's dairy industry must be considered as being subsidised. What happens in fact is that there is a self-balancing fund held at the Reserve Bank by the New Zealand Dairy Production and Marketing Board on behalf of the dairy farmers. Surpluses from export sales of butter and cheese are paid into this fund and deficits are withdrawn. When the fund becomes depleted, as it did in 1966, further deficits are met by the Bank by way of overdraft at a very low rate of interest. This overdraft has, however, to be paid off by the farmers out of surpluses from sales in subsequent years when the guaranteed price is adjusted. It is not always possible to estimate accurately what the guaranteed price should be, so surpluses and deficits keep recurring. The price fixed for butter in any season must not vary by more than 5% from the maximum price fixed for the previous season. The overdraft from the Reserve Bank is thus a debt incurred by the farmers, not a gift from the Bank. The New Zealand Government stands guarantor to the Bank for the overdraft. Basically the New Zealand dairy farmer in the long run receives only what he earns and cannot be described as subsidised. The Minister quoted me as saying that 'the subsidy in New Zealand had been eliminated and was now being paid by the consumer'. What I said, of course, was that 'the consumer subsidy in New Zealand was withdrawn in January of this year'. This appears at page 1533 of Hansard for 20th April 1967. This was the subsidy the New Zealand Government paid to the local butter market to encourage domestic consumption put by lower consumer prices. At the time of its removal in January it was equivalent to The 9.25d per lb in New Zealand currency or 9.6c per lb in Australian currency. As a result of the removal of the subsidy the local price of butter rose from 2s to 2s lOd in New Zealand currency or from 25c to 35.4c per lb in Australian currency. This was to reduce the load on the Treasury. Subsidies on some other foodstuffs were removed at the same time. It is quite clear that the Minister misrepresented me. He said that I had made a little mistake. This was very clever. It suggested that all I had said was wrong. But the Minister was inaccurate and not me. Anybody who chooses to read what I said and what he said, and what I say tonight, will know that I did not make a little mistake but that the Minister misrepresented me. Sir, the record is now straight. Question resolved in the affirmative. House adjourned at 12.21 a.m. (Thursday). Motor Vehicles: Safety Standards (Question No. 87)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: the Prime Minister, upon notice: 1. Does the Commonwealth lay down minimum standards of safety for the motor vehicles it purchases for its own use as the United States Government does? 2. If so, where are the standards publisbed? 3. If not, when was consideration last given to laying down such standards? Mr Harold Holt-The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows: There is a number of Commonwealth transport authorities each of which, when purchasing vehicles, sets minimum safety standards in accordance whh its technical requirements. So far as motor vehicle safety in Australia generally is concerned, I draw the honourable member's attention to the Australian Motor Vehicle Design Advisory Panel which was set up in 1965 by the Australian Transport Advisory Council, which is under the Chairmanship of the Minister for Shipping and Transport. The Panel comprises experts in various fields associated with road safety and was set up to investigate and report on motor vehicles and their component parts and accessories, with a view to reducing road deaths and minimizing the extent and severity of accidents to road users and pedestrians by the production of a safer road vehicle. The Panel has already made a number of recommendations and is continuing its investigations. There has also been functioning for many years an Australian Motor Vehicle Standards Committee on which the Commonwealth Government is represented. The main function of this Committee is to advise the Australian Transport Advisory Council on standards for motor vehicle construction, equipment and performance, including braking and lighting efficiencies, with a view to improving road safety and obtaining uniformity of relevant legislation in the States and.Territories. Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1 and 2. No official records of the incidence of glaucoma in the Australian population generally, or in the population in specific areas of Australia, are available within my Department. However, surveys in other countries indicate an average incidence of 2.5% in persons over forty years of age. A small private survey conducted in Victoria during 1965-66 revealed an incidence of 1.75% in the same age group. Further, expert medical opinion is that bright sunshine is not a causative factor in glaucoma. With regard to diabetes no official records of the incidence of this disease in Australia generally are held by my Department. However, a small private survey conducted in the Australian Capital Territory during 1961 revealed an incidence of approximately 2.5% in the Territory. The incidence of tuberculosis in Australia, in the over forty years age group, is well below 1%. 3. Basic scientific and clinical research relating to glaucoma is currently being carried out in eye hospitals in Sydney and Melbourne. 4. The establishment of clinics in the States for the treatment of glaucoma is a matter for which State authorities are primarily responsible. Pharmaceutical Benefits (Question No. 216)

Speaker: Mr HULME
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1 and 3. The use of radio frequencies in Australia is governed by international agreements to which Australia is a party as a member of the International Telecommunications Union. Member adrninistrauons are required to submit to a body known as the International Frequency Registration Board seasonal schedules of their proposed high frequency usage for broadcasting services. The suitability of frequencies varies with the seasons of the year. This procedure is followed by Australia and all frequencies listed in the current schedule are being used to the full extent of the periods for which they are listed as being available to Australia. They are used by national high frequency stations broadcasting to remote areas in Australia including the north west of Western Australia and by Radio Australia broadcasting to overseas countries. 2. The availability of frequencies in the high quency bands is strictly limited and due to greatly increased use of such frequencies by various countries since the last war there is serious overcrowding of services in these bands. In view of the shortage of frequencies, the assignment of high frequency channels in Australia to private organisations could only be made to the detriment of the national services and Radio Australia. Because of the difficult frequency position there is no prospect of the establishment of commercial high frequency stations in Australia. 4 and 5. An application for additional channels would be considered by the International Frequency Registration Board in its scrutiny of the seasonal channels submitted to it by all administrations. However, where the schedules contain applications for more than one frequency to serve a selected target area, there would be very little prospect of a favourable decision, as the very limited number of channels must be strictly conserved; no action is therefore being taken to apply for further high frequency channel assignments.
